Dropdown menus

Toggleable, contextual menu for displaying lists of links. Made interactive with our dropdown JS plugin.

Dropdown example

Wrap the dropdown’s trigger and the dropdown menu within .dropdown, then add the menu’s HTML.

Clickable element class requirement

In order to provide maximum markup flexibility in Wdesk apps using Web Skin, all clickable elements within dropdowns require the inclusion of the .hitarea CSS class. This allows both <a> and <button> elements to be used interchangeably within dropdowns.

  • Binders
  • Certifications
  • Section 16 
<div class="dropdown">
    <button type="button" class="btn dropdown-toggle"
            aria-haspopup="true"
            aria-expanded="false"
            data-toggle="dropdown">
        Basic Dropdown
        <i class="caret" aria-hidden="true"></i>
    </button>
    <ul role="menu" class="dropdown-menu">
        <li role="presentation">
            <a class="hitarea" tabindex="-1" href="#">Binders</a>
        </li>
        <li role="presentation" class="active">
            <a class="hitarea" tabindex="-1" href="#">Certifications</a>
        </li>
        <li role="presentation">
            <a class="hitarea" tabindex="-1" href="#">Section 16</a>
        </li>
        <li role="presentation">
            <button type="button" class="hitarea" tabindex="-1">XBRL Taxonomy Analyzer</button>
        </li>
    </ul>
</div>
SublimeText Snippet:   wdesk-dropdown  + tab Installation of the Web Skin SublimeText Snippets Package is required.

Dropdown accessibility

Take note of the dropdown button and menu markup shown in this section as it is essential to ensure that your dropdown component is compliant according to WCAG 2.0. Detailed requirements are listed below.

Accessible dropdown button markup

  1. Add aria-haspopup="true" and aria-expanded="false" to the data-toggle="dropdown" element
  2. Add a unique id to the data-toggle="dropdown" element
    1. One will be randomly generated and assigned if you do not
  3. Add aria-hidden="true" to the .caret element
<button type="button" id="{{ dd-btn-id }}" class="btn dropdown-toggle"
            aria-haspopup="true"
            aria-expanded="false"
            data-toggle="dropdown">
        Dropdown Button
        <i class="caret" aria-hidden="true"></i>
    </button>

Accessible dropdown menu markup

  1. Add role="menu" to the dropdown menu
  2. Add aria-labelledby="{{ dd-btn-id }}" to the dropdown menu
  3. Add role="presentation" to each <li> within the dropdown menu
  4. If your .hitarea element within each <li> is not an <a> or <button> tag, add role="button" to it
  5. Add tabindex="-1" to each .hitarea element
<ul role="menu" aria-labelledby="dd-btn-id">
        <li role="presentation">
            <a href="#" tabindex="-1">Link</a>
        </li>
        <li role="presentation">
            <button type="button" tabindex="-1">Button</button>
        </li>
        <li role="presentation">
            <div role="button" tabindex="-1">Div acting like a button</div>
        </li>
    </ul>
Related:  Dropdown JS Plugin Accessibility

Dropdown options

Dropdown menus are highly extensible components, offering a bevy of optional components, alignments and sizes.

Active dropdown items

Add .active to the <li> elem surrounding an action item give it "active" appearance.

  • Binders
  • Certifications
  • Section 16 
<div class="dropdown">
    <ul role="menu" class="dropdown-menu">
        <li role="presentation">
            <a class="hitarea" tabindex="-1" href="#">Binders</a>
        </li>
        <li role="presentation" class="active">
            <a class="hitarea" tabindex="-1" href="#">Certifications</a>
        </li>
        <li role="presentation">
            <a class="hitarea" tabindex="-1" href="#">Section 16</a>
        </li>
        <li role="presentation">
            <button type="button" class="hitarea" tabindex="-1">XBRL Taxonomy Analyzer</button>
        </li>
        ...
    </ul>
</div>

Make active dropdown items accessible

Add aria-selected="true" to the .hitarea element within the li.active element to ensure WCAG 2.0 compliance.

Checked dropdown items

Add .checked to the <li> elem surrounding an action item to give it a checkmark.

  • Binders
  • Certifications
  • Section 16
  • My Profile
  • Sign Out 
<div class="dropdown">
    <ul role="menu" class="dropdown-menu">
        <li role="presentation">
            <a class="hitarea" tabindex="-1" href="#">Binders</a>
        </li>
        <li role="presentation">
            <a class="hitarea" tabindex="-1" href="#" aria-selected="true">Certifications</a>
        </li>
        <li role="presentation" class="checked">
            <a class="hitarea" tabindex="-1" href="#" aria-selected="true">Section 16</a>
        </li>
        <li role="presentation">
            <button type="button" class="hitarea" tabindex="-1">XBRL Taxonomy Analyzer</button>
        </li>
        ...
    </ul>
</div>

Make checked dropdown items accessible

Add aria-selected="true" to the .hitarea element within the li.checked element to ensure WCAG 2.0 compliance.

Dropdown dividers

Add a .divider elem to group actions in any dropdown menu.

  • Binders
  • Certifications
  • Section 16
  • My Profile
  • Sign Out 
<div class="dropdown">
    <ul role="menu" class="dropdown-menu">
        <!-- GROUP 1 ACTIONS HERE -->
        <li role="separator" class="divider"></li>
        <!-- GROUP 2 ACTIONS HERE -->
    </ul>
</div>

Make dropdown dividers accessible

Change role="presentation" to role="separator" when using a li.divider element to ensure WCAG 2.0 compliance.

Dropdown headers

Add a .dropdown-header elem to label groups of actions in any dropdown menu.
Works great in-combination with Dropdown dividers.

  • Accounts
  • Workiva
  • Wells Fargo
  • Google
  • Apps
  • Binders
  • Certifications
  • Section 16
  • My Profile
  • Sign Out 
<div class="dropdown">
    <ul role="menu" class="dropdown-menu">
        <li role="separator" class="dropdown-header">Accounts</li>
        <!-- ACCOUNT ACTION GROUP HERE -->
        <li role="separator" class="divider"></li>
        <li role="separator" class="dropdown-header">Apps</li>
        <!-- APP ACTION GROUP HERE -->
        <li role="separator" class="divider"></li>
        <!-- SOME OTHER UN-LABELED ACTION GROUP HERE -->
    </ul>
</div>

Make dropdown headers accessible

Change role="presentation" to role="separator" when using a li.dropdown-header element to ensure WCAG 2.0 compliance.

Dropdown info panels

Add a non-clickable "info" panel to any dropdown menu.

The standard use-case for this places it at the bottom of a dropdown menu. However, in the case of a dropup menu variation, the info panel should be placed at the top. Another possible use is to place it in-between two groups of menu-links that need to be labeled with more oomph than the standard dropdown header provides.

Change role="presentation" to role="separator" when using a li.dropdown-info element to ensure WCAG 2.0 compliance.

Dropdown alignment

Add .pull-right to a .dropdown-menu or it’s parent .dropdown to right align the dropdown menu. A live example of this can be found in the Button dropdowns section.

<!-- on the menu -->
<ul role="menu" class="dropdown-menu pull-right">
    ...
</ul>

<!-- on the parent -->
<li role="presentation" class="dropdown pull-right">
    ...
</li>

Disabled menu items

Add .disabled to an <a>, or disabled attribute to a <button> in the dropdown to disable the link/button.

Link functionality of <a> not impacted

The .disabled class will only change the appearance of the link, not it’s functionality. Either use custom JS to disable links, or use <button> elems with a disabled attribute instead (recommended).

Make disabled dropdown items accessible

If you choose to use the .disabled class instead of the recommended disabled attribute, add aria-disabled="true" to the .disabled element to ensure WCAG 2.0 compliance.

  • Regular link
  • Disabled link
  • Another link
  • Another link
<ul role="menu" class="dropdown-menu">
    ...
    <li role="presentation">
        <a class="hitarea disabled" href="#" aria-disabled="true">Disabled link</a>
    </li>
    ...
    <li role="presentation">
        <button type="button" class="hitarea" disabled>Disabled button</button>
    </li>
</ul>

Button dropdown menus

Use any button to trigger a dropdown menu by placing it within a .btn-group and providing the proper menu markup.

Plugin dependency

Button dropdowns require the dropdown plugin to be included in your app.

Turn a button into a dropdown toggle with some basic markup changes.

Make split button dropdowns accessible

Add a .sr-only element containing descriptive text adjacent to the .caret elem.

Works with all button sizes

Button dropdowns work with buttons of all sizes. Consider matching up a dropdown size with it’s corresponding button size.

Button groups

Group a series of buttons together on a single line with the button group. Add on optional JavaScript radio and checkbox style behavior with our buttons JS plugin.

Basic button group

Wrap a series of buttons with .btn in .btn-group.

<div class="btn-group">
    <button type="button" class="btn">Left</button>
    <button type="button" class="btn">Middle</button>
    <button type="button" class="btn">Right</button>
</div>
SublimeText Snippet:   wdesk-button:group  + tab Installation of the Web Skin SublimeText Snippets Package is required.

Toggle example

Toggle a button’s active state by adding .active CSS class to the .btn element or elements within a .btn-group to create a toggle control.

Use of our JS buttons plugin is recommended

Since the semantic representation of “toggle” controls in HTML markup are radios and checkboxes, we recommend using them in combination with our buttons plugin to hook your toggle controls into valid HTML form data.

The data-toggle="buttons" attribute in the markup below will automatically wire up this functionality as long as your application is including the buttons plugin.

Inclusive Toggle

When you need to allow the user to select multiple related choices via <input type="checkbox">

Exclusive Toggle

When you need to force the user to select a single related choice via <input type="radio">

<!-- Inclusive Toggle -->
<div class="btn-group" data-toggle="buttons">
    <label class="btn active">
        <input type="checkbox"> Bold
    </label>
    <label class="btn">
        <input type="checkbox"> Italic
    </label>
    <label class="btn">
        <input type="checkbox"> Underline
    </label>
</div>

<!-- Exclusive Toggle -->
<div class="btn-group" data-toggle="buttons">
    <label class="btn active">
        <input type="radio" name="options" id="optionOn"> On
    </label>
    <label class="btn">
        <input type="radio" name="options" id="optionOff"> Off
    </label>
</div>

Button toolbar

Combine sets of <div class="btn-group"> into a <div class="btn-toolbar"> for more complex components.

<div class="btn-toolbar" role="toolbar">
    <div class="btn-group">...</div>
    <div class="btn-group">...</div>
    <div class="btn-group">...</div>
</div>

Toolbar using vertically stacked buttons

Create a toolbar navigation structure using groups of vertical buttons.

Can be used in its own menu as shown in the example below, or within our Subnav “Ribbon” navbar component.

<div class="row">
  <div class="col-xs-7">
    <div class="btn-toolbar pull-right">
      <div class="btn-group">
        <button type="button" class="btn btn-vanilla btn-vertical"
            data-ng-diabled="!fileCanBeMoved"
            disabled>
          <i class="icon icon-two-color icon-twfr-move"></i>
          <small>Move</small>
        </button>
        <button type="button" class="btn btn-vanilla btn-vertical"
            data-ng-diabled="!fileCanBeDeleted"
            disabled>
          <i class="icon icon-two-color icon-twfr-trash"></i>
          <small>Delete</small>
        </button>
        <button type="button" class="btn btn-vanilla btn-vertical">
          <i class="icon icon-two-color icon-twfr-feedback"></i>
          <small>Feedback</small>
        </button>
      </div>
    </div>
  </div>
  <div class="col-xs-5">
    ...
  </div>
</div>

Example uses “vanilla” button styles

The vertically stacked button labels above are shown using the .btn-vanilla utility CSS class. This is how vertically stacked button labels are typically presented in Wdesk apps, but vertically stacked button labels will work with standard button decoration as well.

Vertical button groups

Make a set of buttons appear vertically stacked rather than horizontally.

<div class="btn-group btn-group-vertical">
    ...
</div>
SublimeText Snippet:   wdesk-button:group:vertical  + tab Installation of the Web Skin SublimeText Snippets Package is required.

Justified link variation

Make a group of buttons stretch at the same size to span the entire width of its parent.

Element-specific usage

This only works when the .btn elem is an <a> as the <button> doesn’t pick up the styles we use to justify content (some display: table-cell;-fu).

Not supported in MSIE 7

In MSIE 7 (and below), justified .btn elems will gracefully degrade to behaving as inline-block elements.

Left Right Middle 
<div class="btn-group btn-group-justified">
    ...
</div>

Navs

Navigation components in Web Skin have shared markup, starting with the base .nav class, as well as shared states. Swap modifier classes to switch between each variation.

Clickable element class requirement

In order to provide maximum markup flexibility in Wdesk apps using Web Skin, all clickable elements within navs require the inclusion of the .hitarea CSS class. This allows both <a> and <button> elements to be used interchangeably within navs.

List Nav

Add the .nav-list class to your nav for a vertically stacked list.

  • General
  • XBRL
  • Filing
  • Profile Fields
<ul class="nav nav-list">
    <li role="presentation" class="active">
        <a href="#" class="hitarea" aria-selected="true">General</a>
    </li>
    <li role="presentation">
        <a href="#" class="hitarea">XBRL</a>
    </li>
    <li role="presentation">
        <a href="#" class="hitarea">Filing</a>
    </li>
    <li role="presentation">
        <a href="#" class="hitarea">Profile Fields</a>
    </li>
    <li role="presentation">
        <button type="button" class="hitarea">Authentication</button>
    </li>
</ul>
SublimeText Snippet:   wdesk-nav:nav-list  + tab Installation of the Web Skin SublimeText Snippets Package is required.

Bordered Outlines

Add the .nav-list-bordered class to your existing .nav-list to add an outer border.

  • General
  • XBRL
  • Filing
  • Profile Fields
<ul class="nav nav-list nav-list-bordered">
    ...
</ul>

Collapsible “Tree” Nav

Add the .nav-list-collapsible class to your existing .nav-list for a multi-level vertically stacked list that can be collapsed / expanded with a little help from our collapse plugin.

    <i class="group-icon icon icon-{{ icon-name }}" aria-hidden="true"></i>
    {{ collapsed-item-name }}
  </div>

      aria-hidden="true"

var $collapsingNavDemo      = $('#collapsing-nav-list-example');
var $collapsingNavSections  = $collapsingNavDemo.find('.nav-list.collapse');
var $navSectionContentElems = $('#collapsing-nav-list-content').find('.content-container');

var $activateGroup3Btn      = $('#btn_activateGroup3');
var $collapseAllBtn         = $('#btn_collapseAll');

$collapsingNavSections
    .on('activate.wdesk.collapse', function (e) {
        /*
            The data() within the relatedTarget object on the event
            contains everything you need to manipulate DOM based on
            a new element in the nav list becoming activated
        */
        var btnData = $(e.relatedTarget).data();

        /*
            This contentSelector can be specified
            as anything that is a valid jQuery selector
        */
        var contentSelector = btnData.targetContent;

        if(contentSelector) {
            $.each($navSectionContentElems, function() {
                var $this = $(this);
                if($this.is(contentSelector)) {
                    // its a match... show this content
                    $this.removeClass('hide');
                } else {
                    // not a match... hide this content
                    ! $this.hasClass('hide') && $this.addClass('hide');
                }
            });
        }
    });

$activateGroup3Btn
    .on('click', function (e) {
        $collapsingNavDemo.find('#riskMenu_group3')
            .collapse('activate')
            .collapse('show');

        /*
            Equivalent to the data-api initialization:
            $collapsingNavDemo.find('#btn_riskMenu_group3').click()

            Normally, clicking on an element with [data-toggle=collapse]
            will initialize a collapse instance on the element specified
            by the clicked element's [data-target] or [href], with the
            clicked element passed in as the initial _relatedTarget, which
            will always receive classes related to the collapse element's
            state.

            In this case, since there is no _relatedTarget specified,
            that argument will default to the element specified (by id) by
            the collapsible element's aria-labelledby attribute. In most
            cases, this should refer to the same element that would have
            triggered the collapse element via the data-api.

            This allows classes related to state to be communicated the
            same, regardless of how the collapsible element was initialized.
        */
    });

$collapseAllBtn
    .on('click', function (e) {
        $collapsingNavDemo.find('> li > .collapse').collapse('hide');
    });
SublimeText Snippet:   wdesk-nav:nav-list:collapsible  + tab Installation of the Web Skin SublimeText Snippets Package is required.

Collapsible nav example uses custom JS

The collapsible nav-list example utilizes custom JS that triggers the filtering of the table content by hooking into the built-in collapse plugin events. Your app can wire into the same events to make the collapsible nav perform the actions your use-cases call for.

Click on the JS tab to the right of the code example to see what we are using.

Nested element support

The nested .caret element used in the collapsible nav-list is only supported if the .hitarea element is NOT a <button>. In our examples, we are using <div> elements, but you can use any element you want as long as it has the .hitarea CSS class.

If you choose to not use an <a>, be sure you switch the href attribute to a data-target attribute.

See this article for more information.

Using hashbang targets with AngularJS

If you are using AngularJS for your Wdesk app, DO NOT USE <a> elements in combination with the data-toggle="collapse" href="#toggleElem" attribute pattern. AngularJS reserves hashbang for routing - and in Internet Explorer, the whole page will refresh when you click an element that should only perform the toggle.

We recommend using another element like a <button> or <div>, while adding an appropriate role and tabindex attributes for accessibility.

<div role="button" tabindex="0" data-toggle="collapse"
     data-target="#toggleElem"
     aria-controls="toggleElem">
    Toggle Me
</div>

See this article for more information.

Collapsible Nav Accessibility

Take note of the collapsible nav markup shown in this section as it is essential to ensure that your component is compliant according to WCAG 2.0.

Related:  Collapse JS Plugin Accessibility

Base nav list

  1. Add role="tree" to the .nav-list element
  2. Add role="presentation" to each .nav-list > .nav-group element
<ul role="tree" class="nav nav-list nav-list-collapsible">
      <li role="presentation" class="nav-group">
        ...
      </li>
      <li role="presentation" class="nav-group">
        ...
      </li>
    </ul>

All tree branches

Parent collapse toggle “treeitem”:
  1. Add attributes role="treeitem", tabindex="0", aria-selected="false" and aria-expanded="false"
  2. Add aria-controls attribute with a value equal to the ID of the child .nav-list element that it controls
  3. Add aria-hidden="true" to the .caret element
Collapsible child “group”:
  1. Add attributes tabindex="-1" and aria-hidden="true"
  2. Add a unique ID so the associated treeitem element can use it in it’s aria-controls attribute
  3. Add aria-labelledby attribute with a value equal to the ID of the associated treeitem element that controls it
<li role="presentation" class="nav-group">
  <div role="treeitem" id="{{ collapsed-btn-id }}" tabindex="0"
       class="hitarea collapsed"
       aria-expanded="false"
       aria-selected="false"
       aria-controls="{{ collapsed-group-id }}">
    <i class="caret" aria-hidden="true"></i>
    <i class="group-icon icon icon-{{ icon-name }}" aria-hidden="true"></i>
    {{ collapsed-item-name }}
  </div>
  <ul role="group" id="{{ collapsed-group-id }}" tabindex="-1"
      class="nav nav-list collapse"
      aria-hidden="true"
      aria-labelledby="{{ collapsed-btn-id }}">
  </ul>
</li>

Initially expanded branches

The collapse JS plugin will handle the toggling of these attributes when tree branches are expanded/collapsed dynamically. However, for the initial state of your group of collapsible branches, if you have a branch that is expanded, set the attributes as described below.

Parent collapse toggle “treeitem”:
  1. Change aria-selected and aria-expanded attribute values to true
Collapsible child “group”:
  1. Change tabindex attribute value to 0
  2. Change aria-hidden attribute value to false
<li role="presentation" class="nav-group">
  <div role="treeitem" id="{{ expanded-btn-id }}" tabindex="0"
       class="hitarea collapsed open"
       aria-expanded="true"
       aria-selected="{{ isSelected }}"
       aria-controls="{{ expanded-group-id }}">
    <i class="caret" aria-hidden="true"></i>
    <i class="group-icon icon icon-{{ icon-name }}" aria-hidden="true"></i>
    {{ expanded-item-name }}
  </div>
  <ul role="group" id="{{ expanded-group-id }}" tabindex="0"
      class="nav nav-list collapse in"
      aria-hidden="false"
      aria-labelledby="{{ expanded-btn-id }}">
    ...
  </ul>
</li>

Additional markup required for collapse data-api

The collapsing nav component attributes listed above pertain only to accessibility - not the dynamic data-api functionality of the component. Please reference the collapse data-api documentation to ensure all the required data-api attributes are present in your implementation.

Collapsible Nav Dividers

By default, a .nav-list-collapsible component does not have borders between adjacent list items. If you have multiple "groups" of collapsing lists, use the .nav-group-border CSS class to any existing top-level <li> to add a border

Accessibility

Take note of the tabbed navigation / content markup shown in this section as it is essential to ensure that your component is compliant according to WCAG 2.0.

Tab navigation elements

  1. Add role="tablist" on each .nav-tabs element
  2. Add role="presentation" on all <li> elments within .nav-tabs
  3. Add role="tab", tabindex="0" and aria-selected="false" to each data-toggle="tab" element
  4. Change the value of aria-selected to true on the data-toggle="tab" element that is intially selected
  5. Add aria-controls to each data-toggle="tab" element with a value equal to the ID of the tabpanel element that it controls
  6. Add a unique ID to each data-toggle="tab" element so their associated tabpanel element can use it in their aria-labelledby attribute
<ul role="tablist" class="nav nav-tabs">
      <!-- active tab -->
      <li role="presentation" class="active">
        <a role="tab" href="#{{ tab-content-id }}" id="{{ tab-id }}" tabindex="0"
           class="hitarea"
           aria-controls="{{ tab-content-id }}"
           aria-selected="true"
           data-toggle="tab">
          {{ tab-name }}
        </a>
      </li>

      <!-- inactive tab -->
      <li role="presentation">
        <a role="tab" href="#{{ tab-two-content-id }}" id="{{ tab-two-id }}" tabindex="0"
           class="hitarea"
           aria-controls="{{ tab-two-content-id }}"
           aria-selected="false"
           data-toggle="tab">
          {{ tab-two-name }}
        </a>
      </li>
    </ul>

Tab content elements

  1. Add role="tabpanel", aria-hidden="true" and tabindex="-1" to each .tab-pane element
  2. Change the value of aria-hidden to false, and tabindex to 0 for the content pane that is initially visible/active
  3. Add aria-labelledby to each tabpanel element with a value equal to the ID of the data-toggle="tab" element that controls it
  4. Add a unique ID to each tabpanel element so their associated data-toggle="tab" element can use it in their aria-controls attribute
<div class="tab-content">
      <!-- active tab content -->
      <div role="tabpanel" id="{{ tab-content-id }}" tabindex="0"
           class="tab-pane in"
           aria-hidden="false"
           aria-labelledby="{{ tab-id }}">
        ...
      </div>

      <!-- inactive tab content -->
      <div role="tabpanel" id="{{ tab-two-content-id }}" tabindex="-1"
           class="tab-pane"
           aria-hidden="true"
           aria-labelledby="{{ tab-two-id }}">
        ...
      </div>
    </div>
Related:  Tab JS Plugin Accessibility

Justified nav links

Easily make tabs or pills equal widths of their parent at screens wider than with .nav-justified. On smaller screens, the nav links are stacked.

Safari and responsive justified navs

As of v7.0.1, Safari exhibits a bug in which resizing your browser horizontally causes rendering errors in the justified nav that are cleared upon refreshing.

Element-specific usage

This only works when the .hitarea elem is an <a> as the <button> doesn’t pick up the styles we use to justify content (some display: table-cell;-fu).

Not supported in MSIE 7

In MSIE 7 (and below), justified .hitarea elems will gracefully degrade to behaving as inline-block elements.

Active nav links

For any of the nav components, add .active class to a .hitarea’s parent <li> element to “activate” the nav item.

Active pills

  • Clickable link
  • Clickable link
  • Active link 
<ul class="nav nav-pills">
    <li role="presentation" class="active">
        <a href="#" class="hitarea disabled" aria-selected="true">Active link</a>
    </li>
</ul>

Active tabs

  • Clickable tab
  • Clickable tab
  • Active tab 
<ul role="tablist" class="nav nav-tabs">
    <li role="presentation" class="active">
        <a role="tab" href="#" class="hitarea disabled" aria-selected="true">Active link</a>
    </li>
</ul>

Active list items

  • Clickable link
  • Clickable link
  • Active link 
<ul class="nav nav-list">
    <li role="presentation" class="active">
        <a href="#" class="hitarea disabled" aria-selected="true">Active link</a>
    </li>
</ul>

Make active nav links accessible

When styling a nav link using the .active CSS class, it is essential to also semantically “activate” the element by adding aria-selected="true" to the .hitarea elem within the active <li> to ensure WCAG 2.0 compliance.

Disabled nav links

For any of the nav components, add .disabled class to a link or disabled attribute to a button inside the nav’s <li> to disable the nav item.

Disabled pills

  • Clickable link
  • Clickable link
  • Disabled link 
<ul class="nav nav-pills">
    <!-- requires js to actually disable functionality -->
    <li role="presentation">
        <a href="#" class="hitarea disabled" aria-disabled="true">Disabled link</a>
    </li>
    <!-- functionality disabled natively via browser -->
    <li role="presentation">
        <button type="button" class="hitarea" disabled>Disabled button</button>
    </li>
</ul>

Disabled tabs

  • Clickable tab
  • Clickable tab
  • Disabled tab 
<ul role="tablist" class="nav nav-tabs">
    <!-- requires js to actually disable functionality -->
    <li role="presentation">
        <a role="tab" href="#" class="hitarea disabled" aria-disabled="true">Disabled link</a>
    </li>
    <!-- functionality disabled natively via browser -->
    <li role="presentation">
        <button role="tab" type="button" class="hitarea" disabled>Disabled button</button>
    </li>
</ul>

Disabled list items

  • Clickable link
  • Clickable link
  • Disabled link 
<ul class="nav nav-list">
    <!-- requires js to actually disable functionality -->
    <li role="presentation">
        <a href="#" class="hitarea disabled" aria-disabled="true">Disabled link</a>
    </li>
    <!-- functionality disabled natively via browser -->
    <li role="presentation">
        <button type="button" class="hitarea" disabled>Disabled button</button>
    </li>
</ul>

Link functionality of <a> not impacted

The .disabled class will only change the appearance of the link, not it’s functionality. Either use custom JS to disable links, or use <button> elems with a disabled attribute instead (recommended).

Make disabled nav links accessible

If you choose to use the .disabled class instead of the recommended disabled attribute, add aria-disabled="true" to the .disabled element to ensure WCAG 2.0 compliance.

Directional Wizards

Easily make justified pills into a step-by-step "wizard" with .nav-wizard. Use .completed in addition to .active to mark a step as "done".

Status Only (Default)

<ul class="nav nav-pills nav-justified nav-wizard">
    <!-- Completed Step -->
    <li role="presentation" class="active completed">
        <button role="menuitemcheckbox" class="hitarea"
           aria-checked="true">
            <i class="icon" aria-hidden="true"></i>
            Step 1
        </button>
        <!-- First <li role="presentation"> has no arrow -->
    </li>
    <!-- Current Step -->
    <li role="presentation" class="active">
        <button role="menuitemcheckbox" class="hitarea"
           aria-checked="false"
           aria-selected="true">
            <i class="icon" aria-hidden="true"></i> Step 2
        </button>
        <div class="wizard-inner" aria-hidden="true">
            <i class="wizard-arrow"></i>
        </div>
    </li>
    <!-- Next Steps -->
    <li role="presentation">
        <button type="button" class="hitarea">
            <i class="icon"></i>
            Step 3
        </button>
        <div class="wizard-inner"><i class="wizard-arrow"></i></div>
    </li>
    <li role="presentation">
        <button role="menuitemcheckbox" class="hitarea"
           aria-checked="false">
            <i class="icon" aria-hidden="true"></i>
            Step 3
        </button>
        <div class="wizard-inner" aria-hidden="true">
            <i class="wizard-arrow"></i>
        </div>
    </li>
    <li role="presentation">
        <button role="menuitemcheckbox" class="hitarea"
           aria-checked="false">
            <i class="icon" aria-hidden="true"></i>
            Step 4
        </button>
        <div class="wizard-inner" aria-hidden="true">
            <i class="wizard-arrow"></i>
        </div>
    </li>
</ul>

               aria-checked="true">

        </li>
        <!-- Current Step -->

            <a role="menuitemcheckbox" class="hitarea" href="#step2"

Pagination

Provide pagination links for your site or app with the multi-page pagination component, or the simpler pager alternative.

Standard pagination

Simple pagination inspired by Rdio, great for apps and search results. The large block is hard to miss, easily scalable, and provides large click areas.

    </li>
    <li role="menuitemradio" aria-checked="false">
        <a class="hitarea" href="#">1</a>
    </li>
    <li role="menuitemradio" aria-checked="false">
        <a class="hitarea" href="#">2</a>
    </li>
    <li role="menuitemradio" aria-checked="false">
        <a class="hitarea" href="#">3</a>
    </li>
    <li role="menuitemradio" aria-checked="false">
        <a class="hitarea" href="#">4</a>
    </li>

        <a class="hitarea" href="#">5</a>
    </li>

Disabled and active states

Links are customizable for different circumstances. Use .disabled css class on a link or disabled attribute on a button for unclickable links and .active on the parent <li> to indicate the current page.

  • «
  • 1
  • 2
  • 3
  • 4
  • 5
  • » 
<ul role="menu" class="nav pagination">
    ...
    <li role="menuitemradio" aria-checked="true" class="active">
        <a href="#" class="hitarea">1</a>
    </li>
    ...
    <li role="menuitemradio" aria-checked="false">
        <a href="#" class="hitarea disabled" aria-disabled="true">4</a>
    </li>
    ...
    <li role="menuitemradio" aria-checked="false">
        <button type="button" class="hitarea" disabled>6</button>
    </li>
</ul>

Link functionality of <a> not impacted

The .disabled class will only change the appearance of the link, not it’s functionality. Either use custom JS to disable links, or use <button> elems with a disabled attribute instead (recommended).

Make pagination controls accessible

Take note of the pagination markup shown in this section as it is essential to ensure that your component is compliant according to WCAG 2.0.

  1. Add role="menu" to the .page-indicators element
  2. Add role="menuitemradio" to each <li>
  3. If you choose to use the .disabled class instead of the recommended disabled attribute, add aria-disabled="true" to the .disabled element
  4. Add aria-checked="false" to each <li>, and change it’s value to true when adding the .active CSS class

Pager

Quick previous and next links for simple pagination implementations with light markup and styles. It’s great for simple sites like blogs or magazines.

Default example

By default, the pager centers links.

  • Previous
  • Next 
<ul class="nav pager">
    <li role="presentation">
        <a class="hitarea" href="#">Previous</a>
    </li>
    <li role="presentation">
        <a class="hitarea" href="#">Next</a>
    </li>
</ul>
SublimeText Snippet:   wdesk-pager  + tab Installation of the Web Skin SublimeText Snippets Package is required.

Aligned links

Alternatively, you can align each link to the sides:

  • ← Older
  • Newer →
<ul class="nav pager">
    <li role="presentation" class="previous">
        <a class="hitarea" href="#">&larr; Older</a>
    </li>
    <li role="presentation" class="next">
        <a class="hitarea" href="#">Newer &rarr;</a>
    </li>
</ul>
SublimeText Snippet:   wdesk-pager:aligned  + tab Installation of the Web Skin SublimeText Snippets Package is required.

Optional disabled state

Pager links also use the general .disabled utility class or disabled form element attribute from the pagination component.

Using a.disabled
  • ← Older
  • Newer →
Using button[disabled]
<!-- using .disabled class -->
<ul class="nav pager">
    <li role="presentation" class="previous">
        <a class="hitarea disabled" href="#" aria-disabled="true">
            &larr; Older
        </a>
    </li>
    <li role="presentation" class="next">
        <a class="hitarea" href="#">
            Newer &rarr;
        </a>
    </li>
</ul>
<!-- using disabled attribute -->
<ul class="nav pager">
    <li role="presentation" class="previous">
        <button type="button" class="hitarea" disabled>
            &larr; Older
        </button>
    </li>
    <li role="presentation" class="next">
        <button type="button" class="hitarea">
            Newer &rarr;
        </button>
    </li>
</ul>

Link functionality of <a> not impacted

The .disabled class will only change the appearance of the link, not it’s functionality. Either use custom JS to disable links, or use <button> elems with a disabled attribute instead (recommended).

Make pager links accessible

If you choose to use the .disabled class instead of the recommended disabled attribute, add aria-disabled="true" to the .disabled element to ensure WCAG 2.0 compliance.

Page Indicator Controls

Page indicator controls indicate the number of open views/pages, and which one is currently visible using the .active CSS class.

  • Page 1
  • Page 2
  • Page 3
  • Page 4 
<ul role="menu" class="page-indicators">
    <li role="menuitemradio" aria-checked="false">
        <i class="sr-only">Page 1</i>
    </li>
    <li role="menuitemradio" aria-checked="true" class="active">
        <i class="sr-only">Page 2</i>
    </li>
    <li role="menuitemradio" aria-checked="false">
        <i class="sr-only">Page 3</i>
    </li>
    <li role="menuitemradio" aria-checked="false">
        <i class="sr-only">Page 4</i>
    </li>
</ul>

Make page indicator controls accessible

Take note of the page indicator navigation markup shown in this section as it is essential to ensure that your component is compliant according to WCAG 2.0.

  1. Add role="menu" to the .page-indicators element
  2. Add role="menuitemradio" to each <li>
  3. Add some descriptive text using the .sr-only CSS class within each <li>
  4. Add aria-checked="false" to each <li>, and change it’s value to true when adding the .active CSS class

Navbar

Navbars are responsive meta components that serve as primary navigation for your Wdesk application. They begin collapsed and toggleable in mobile views, and become horizontal as the available viewport width increases.

Overflowing content

Since Web Skin doesn’t know how much space the content in your navbar needs, you might run into issues with content wrapping into a second row. To resolve this, you can:

  1. Reduce the amount or width of navbar items.
  2. Hide certain navbar items at certain screen sizes using responsive utility classes.
  3. Change the point at which your navbar switches between collapsed and horizontal mode. Customize the $gridFloatBreakpoint Sass variable or add your own media query.

Requires JavaScript

If JavaScript is disabled and the viewport is narrow enough that the navbar collapses, it will be impossible to expand the navbar and view the content within the .nav-collapse.

Standard navbar

The standard navbar for Wdesk apps uses the navbar-fixed-top display variation.

Make navbars accessible

Be sure to add a role="navigation" to every navbar to ensure WCAG 2.0 compliance.

Plugin dependency

The responsive navbar requires the collapse plugin to be included in your app.

Fixed position & iOS input focus

Mobile Safari (iOS) exhibits non-standard behavior upon input focus (virtual keyboard visible) for elems using fixed positioning. This is not handled by Web Skin, so it is up to you to decide which solution is best for your app. Some suggestions are provided below:

Single page / mobile app (webview zoom disabled)

Add the following meta tag in the <head> of your page:

<meta name="viewport" content="width=device-width,
                               initial-scale=1.0,
                               maximum-scale=1.0,
                               target-densityDpi=device-dpi">
Web site / desktop app (browser zoom enabled)

Add the following CSS to override the Web Skin defaults.

/**
 * Be sure this CSS is included AFTER the core wdesk.css styles.
 */
.navbar-fixed-top,
.navbar-fixed-bottom {
    position: absolute;
}

Related: Modal fixed positioning on mobile devices

Plugin dependency

The Ribbon sub-navigation requires the tabs plugin to be included in your app.

Navbar components

Clickable element class requirement

In order to provide maximum markup flexibility in Wdesk apps using Web Skin, all clickable elements within navbars require the inclusion of the .hitarea CSS class. This allows both <a> and <button> elements to be used interchangeably within navbars.

Nav links

Nav items are simple to add via unordered lists.
  • Home
  • Link
  • Disabled 
<ul role="menu" class="nav navbar-nav">
    <li role="presentation" class="active">
        <a href="#" class="hitarea" aria-selected="true">Home</a>
    </li>
    <li role="presentation">
        <a href="#" class="hitarea">Link</a>
    </li>
    <li role="presentation">
        <a href="#" class="hitarea disabled" aria-disabled="true">Disabled</a>
    </li>
</ul>
SublimeText Snippet:   wdesk-navbar:navbar-nav  + tab Installation of the Web Skin SublimeText Snippets Package is required.

Block nav links

Simply add .nav-blocks to any .navbar-nav menu to get full-height "blocks" of links, perfect for housing icon-only hitareas. Primarily used in tablet viewer navbars.

Centering icons

In order to center icons within .hitarea elements like those shown in the block nav link example above, add the .no-text helper class to zero-out any margin from the icon itself.

 
<ul role="menu" class="nav navbar-nav nav-blocks pull-right">
    <li role="presentation">
        <button type="button" class="hitarea no-text">
            <i class="icon icon-md icon-cog" aria-hidden="true"></i>
            <i class="sr-only">Settings</i>
        </button>
    </li>
    <li role="presentation">
        <button type="button" class="hitarea no-text">
            <i class="icon icon-comment" aria-hidden="true"></i>
            <i class="sr-only">Add Comment</i>
        </button>
    </li>
</ul>

Make icon-only links accessible

Be sure to add some descriptive text to any button that only has an icon visible using the .sr-only class to ensure WCAG 2.0 compliance.

Disabled nav links

For any of the navbar nav links, add .disabled to the <li>, or attribute disabled to a button inside the nav’s <li> to disable the link/button.
  • Home
  • Link
  • Disabled link 
<ul role="menu" class="nav navbar-nav">
    <!-- disabled class -->
    <li role="presentation">
        <a href="#" class="hitarea disabled" aria-disabled="true">Disabled link</a>
    </li>
    <!-- disabled attribute -->
    <li role="presentation">
        <button type="button" class="hitarea" disabled>Disabled button</button>
    </li>
</ul>
<ul role="menu" class="nav navbar-nav nav-blocks pull-right">
    <!-- disabled class -->
    <li role="presentation">
        <button type="button" class="hitarea no-text disabled" aria-disabled="true">
            <i class="icon icon-md icon-cog" aria-hidden="true"></i>
            <i class="sr-only">Settings</i>
        </button>
    </li>
    <!-- disabled attribute -->
    <li role="presentation">
        <button type="button" class="hitarea no-text" disabled>
            <i class="icon icon-comment" aria-hidden="true"></i>
            <i class="sr-only">Add Comment</i>
        </button>
    </li>
</ul>

Link functionality of <a> not impacted

The .disabled class will only change the appearance of the link, not it’s functionality. Either use custom JS to disable links, or use <button> elems with a disabled attribute instead (recommended).

Make disabled nav links accessible

If you choose to use the .disabled class instead of the recommended disabled attribute, add aria-disabled="true" to the .disabled element to ensure WCAG 2.0 compliance.

Buttons in a navbar

Add the .navbar-btn CSS class to vertically center buttons within a navbar.
  • Home
  • Link
  • Disabled link 
<nav role="navigation" class="navbar">
    ...
    <button type="button" class="btn btn-xs btn-primary navbar-btn pull-right">
        Sign in
    </button>
</nav>
SublimeText Snippet:   wdesk-navbar:navbar-button  + tab Installation of the Web Skin SublimeText Snippets Package is required.

Context-specific usage

Like the standard button classes, .navbar-btn can be used on <a> and <input> elements. However, neither .navbar-btn nor the standard .btn classes should be used on <a> elements within .navbar-nav.

Text in a navbar

Wrap strings of text in an element with .navbar-text, usually on a <p> tag for proper leading and color.
  • Home
  • Link
  • Disabled link

Signed in as Abraham Lincoln

<nav role="navigation" class="navbar">
    ...
    <p class="navbar-text pull-right">Signed in as Abraham Lincoln</p>
</nav>
SublimeText Snippet:   wdesk-navbar:navbar-text  + tab Installation of the Web Skin SublimeText Snippets Package is required.

Non-nav links

For folks using standard links that are not within the regular navbar navigation component, use the .navbar-link class to add the proper colors for a navbar.
  • Home
  • Link
  • Disabled link

Signed in as Abraham Lincoln

<nav role="navigation" class="navbar">
  ...
  <p class="navbar-text pull-right">Signed in as <a href="#" class="hitarea navbar-link">Abraham Lincoln</a></p>
</nav>
SublimeText Snippet:   wdesk-navbar:navbar-link  + tab Installation of the Web Skin SublimeText Snippets Package is required.

Component alignment

Align nav links, forms, buttons, or text, using the .pull-left or .pull-right utility classes. Both classes will add a CSS float in the specified direction. To align nav links, put them in a separate <ul> with the respective utility class applied.

Optional display variations

Fixed position & iOS input focus

Mobile Safari (iOS) exhibits non-standard behavior upon input focus (virtual keyboard visible) for elems using fixed positioning. This is not handled by Web Skin, so it is up to you to decide which solution is best for your app. Some suggestions are provided below:

Single page / mobile app (webview zoom disabled)

Add the following meta tag in the <head> of your page:

<meta name="viewport" content="width=device-width,
                               initial-scale=1.0,
                               maximum-scale=1.0,
                               target-densityDpi=device-dpi">
Web site / desktop app (browser zoom enabled)

Add the following CSS to override the Web Skin defaults.

/**
 * Be sure this CSS is included AFTER the core wdesk.css styles.
 */
.navbar-fixed-top,
.navbar-fixed-bottom {
    position: absolute;
}

Related: Modal fixed positioning on mobile devices

Static top navbar

Create a full-width navbar that scrolls away with the page by adding .navbar-static-top and include a .container to center and pad navbar content.
  • Home
  • Link
  • Link 
<nav role="navigation" class="navbar navbar-static-top">
    <div class="container">
        ...
    </div>
</nav>
SublimeText Snippet:   wdesk-navbar:static-top  + tab Installation of the Web Skin SublimeText Snippets Package is required.

Fixed to top

Add .navbar-fixed-top and include a .container to center and pad navbar content.
  • Home

SublimeText Snippet:   wdesk-navbar:fixed-top  + tab Installation of the Web Skin SublimeText Snippets Package is required.

Body padding required

The fixed navbar will overlay your other content, unless you add padding to the top of the <body>. Try out your own values or use our snippet below. Tip: By default, the navbar is high.

body { padding-top: $navbarHeight + $lineHeightBasePx; }


Make sure to include this after the core Web Skin CSS.

Fixed to bottom

Add .navbar-fixed-bottom and include a .container to center and pad navbar content.

Body padding required

The fixed navbar will overlay your other content, unless you add padding to the bottom of the <body>. Try out your own values or use our snippet below. Tip: By default, the navbar is high.

body { padding-bottom: $navbarHeight + $lineHeightBasePx; }


Make sure to include this after the core Web Skin CSS.

Badges

Easily highlight new or unread items by adding a <span class="badge"> to links, Web Skin navs, and more.

Example

Inbox 42 
<a href="#">Inbox <span class="badge">42</span></a>
SublimeText Snippet:   wdesk-badge  + tab Installation of the Web Skin SublimeText Snippets Package is required.

Self collapsing

When there are no new or unread items, badges will simply collapse (via CSS’s :empty selector) provided no content exists within.

Cross-browser compatibility

Badges won’t self collapse in Internet Explorer 8 because it lacks support for the :empty CSS selector.

Adapts to active / disabled nav states

Built-in styles are included for placing badges in active and disabled states in tab, pill and list navigations.

Tooltip accessibility

Take note of the tooltip markup shown in this section as it is essential to ensure that your component is compliant according to WCAG 2.0.

  1. If you customize the tooltip template option, add role="tooltip" to your primary tooltip container
  2. If you customize the tooltip template option, add aria-hidden="true" to your .arrow element
  3. If you customize the tooltip backdrop option, add role="presentation" to your .tooltip-backdrop element
<div role="tooltip" class="tooltip">
        <div class="arrow" aria-hidden="true"></div>
        <div class="inner">...</div>
    </div>
    <div role="presentation" class="tooltip-backdrop backdrop"></div>
Related:  Tooltip JS Plugin Accessibility

Variations

Check out the form validation demo for a working example.

<div role="tooltip" class="popover">

            <div class="content">
                ...
            </div>
        </div>
    </div>

Popover Comment Markup

HTML Markup Demonstrates View State

The markup for popover comments is highly dynamic, so we’re illustrating the dynamic CSS classes and elements shown below using pseudo-AngularJS markup. Obviously, to wire up this functionality in your application, you'll need to toggle these classes and elements according to actual logic.

We’ve done our best to demonstrate the intent of the interactions according to UX specification. However, if you have questions, or find flaws with the logic demonstrated here, please reach out to us via HipChat or Github so we can help.

Our platform is intended to save you time - not become an obstruction.

<div class="popover fade in top popover-comment dialog-gray" role="tooltip"
     data-ng-class="{'popover-thread': isSharedComment,
                     'popover-thread-closed: isThreadClosed',
                     'new-comment': isCommentNew,
                     'modal-open': isModalConfirmationVisible}">
    <div class="arrow" aria-hidden="true"></div>
    <div class="inner">
        <div class="navbar title comment-header"
             data-ng-switch="isNewComment">
            <h3 class="comment-title">
                <i class="icon icon-md"
                   data-ng-class="{'icon-comment-private-note': ! isSharedComment
                                   'icon-comment-alt': isSharedComment
                                   'icon-comment-outlined': isThreadClosed}">
                </i>
                {{ commentAuthorName }}
            </h3>
            <div class="comment-meta pull-right">
                <div class="comment-type-toggle"
                     data-on="true">
                    <div class="checkbox-switch checkbox-switch-xs checkbox-switch-alt">
                        <input type="checkbox" id="private-comment-toggle-{{comment.id}}"
                               data-ng-model="isSharedComment">
                        <label for="private-comment-toggle-{{comment.id}}"></label>
                    </div>
                </div>
                <small class="comment-timestamp text-sm text-muted"
                       data-on="false">
                    {{ timeago(date.now) }}
                </small>
                <div role="menu" class="dropdown pull-right"
                    data-on="false">
                    <li role="presentation" class="dropdown pull-right">
                        <button type="button" id="thread-options-btn"
                                class="hitarea dropdown-toggle no-text"
                                data-toggle="dropdown">
                            <i class="caret" aria-hidden="true"></i>
                        </button>
                        <ul role="menu" id="thread-options-menu"
                            class="dropdown-menu"
                            aria-labelledby="thread-options-btn">
                            <li role="presentation">
                                <button type="button" id="thread-delete-btn"
                                        class="hitarea"
                                        data-toggle="modal"
                                        data-parent-container=".popover-comment"
                                        data-container=".comments"
                                        data-target="#thread-modal-confirmation">
                                    <i class="icon icon-trash"></i>
                                    Delete Comment Thread
                                </button>
                            </li>
                            <li role="presentation">
                                <button type="button" id="thread-close-btn" class="hitarea">
                                    <i class="icon"
                                       data-ng-class="{'icon-comment-checkmark': !isThreadClosed,
                                                       'icon-comment-reopen': isThreadClosed}"></i>
                                    {{ Close||Reopen }} Comment Thread
                                </button>
                            </li>
                            <li role="presentation">
                                <button type="button" id="thread-convert-btn" class="hitarea"
                                        data-ng-disabled="!canMakeCommentPrivate">
                                    <i class="icon icon-lock"></i>
                                    Make Private
                                </button>
                            </li>
                        </ul>
                    </li>
                </div>
            </div>
        </div><!-- END .comment-header -->

        <div class="comments">
            <div id="thread-comment{{comment.id}}" class="comment comment-editing"
                  data-ng-repeat="comment in comments"
                  data-ng-class="{'comment-readonly': !editingComment
                                  'comment-editing': editingComment
                                  'comment-last': isLastOrOnlyThreadComment()}"
                  data-ng-switch="editingComment">
                <div class="cblock comment-meta"
                     data-ng-class="{'hide': isFirstOrOnlyComment}"
                     data-on="false">
                    <strong class="comment-author text-sm pull-left">
                        {{ commentAuthorName }}
                    </strong>
                    <em class="comment-timestamp text-sm pull-right">
                        {{ timeago(date.now) }}
                    </em>
                </div>
                <div class="cblock comment-body">
                    <label class="sr-only" for="thread-comment{{comment.id}}-text">
                        {{ getCommentLabel(comment.type) }}
                    </label>
                    <textarea id="thread-comment{{comment.id}}-text"
                              class="form-control"
                              placeholder="{{ getCommentLabel(comment.type) }}"
                              data-ng-class="{'input-vanilla': !editingComment}"
                              data-ng-readonly="!editingComment"></textarea>
                </div>
                <!--
                    The .comment-reply block would only be present
                    in the :last .comment elem within .inner in a
                    thread that had at least one comment

                    Also, this block wouldn't exist at all if it was a private comment
                -->
                <div class="cblock comment-reply comment-reply-empty hide"
                     data-ng-class="{ 'show': comments.length > 0 && thisIsTheLastComment() && confirmationModalIsNotOpen()
                                      'comment-reply-empty': replyTextareaIsEmpty() }">
                    <textarea id="thread-comment{{comment.id}}-reply" class="form-control"
                              placeholder="Reply to this comment"></textarea>

                    <!--
                        Another confirmation modal would need to
                        be injected here for discarding reply confirmation
                    -->
                </div>
                <div class="cblock comment-actions collapse"
                     data-ng-class="{in: editingComment}">
                    <div class="nav-tooltip">
                        <ul class="nav nav-pills nav-justified halve">
                            <li>
                                <button type="button" class="hitarea delete-hover"
                                        data-ng-disabled="isEmptyComment('#thread-comment{{comment.id}}-{{text||reply}}')"
                                        data-toggle="modal"
                                        data-parent-container=".popover-comment"
                                        data-container=".comment"
                                        data-target="#thread-comment{{comment.id}}-modal">
                                    {{ deleteDiscardBtnText }}
                                </button>
                            </li>
                            <li>
                                <button type="submit" class="hitarea"
                                        data-ng-disabled="isEmptyComment('#thread-comment{{comment.id}}-{{text||reply}}')"
                                        disabled>
                                    {{ savePostBtnText }}
                                </button>
                            </li>
                        </ul>
                    </div>
                </div>
                <div id="thread-comment{{comment.id}}-modal"
                     class="modal contained fade confirmation-modal">
                    <!-- comment-level modal confirmation content -->
                </div>
            </div><!-- END .comment -->
            <div id="thread-modal-confirmation" class="modal contained fade confirmation-modal">
                <!-- thread-level modal confirmation content -->
            </div>
        </div><!-- END .comments (thread) -->
        <div class="backdrop thread-overlay">
            <div class="thread-status">
                {{ thread.statusText }}
            </div>
        </div>
    </div>
</div>

Alert Dialogs

Provide contextual feedback and alert messages to Wdesk users using our alert JS plugin.

Default alert

Wrap any text and an optional dismiss button in .alert for a basic confirmation alert message. To ensure proper behavior across all devices, be sure to use <button> element with the data-dismiss="alert" data attribute.

Heads Up! I’m telling you this for your own good.

<div role="alert" class="alert fade" aria-live="polite">
    <button type="button" class="close" data-dismiss="alert">
        <i aria-hidden="true">&times;</i>
        <i class="sr-only">Close</i>
    </button>
    <p><strong>Heads Up!</strong> I&rsquo;m telling you this for your own good.</p>
</div>
SublimeText Snippet:   wdesk-alert  + tab Installation of the Web Skin SublimeText Snippets Package is required.

Accessibility

Take note of the alert dialog markup shown in this section as it is essential to ensure that your component is compliant according to WCAG 2.0.

  1. Add role="alert" to your primary alert container
  2. Add aria-live to your alert container
    1. aria-live="polite" for non-critical messages
    2. aria-live="assertive" for critical messages
  3. Use descriptive text inside the .close button using the .sr-only helper class
<div role="alert" class="alert alert-success" aria-live="polite">
        <button type="button" class="close" data-dismiss="alert">
        <i aria-hidden="true">&times;</i>
        <i class="sr-only">Close</i>
    </button>
    </div>
    <div role="alert" class="alert alert-warning" aria-live="assertive">
        <button type="button" class="close" data-dismiss="alert">
        <i aria-hidden="true">&times;</i>
        <i class="sr-only">Close</i>
    </button>
    </div>
Related:  Alert JS Plugin Accessibility

Well done! You successfully read this important alert message.

Warning! Better check yourself, you’re not looking too good.

Oh snap! Change a few things up and try again.

Nested alerts

When an alert message is isolated to another component, sometimes it is appropriate to add the .alert-sm size variation class so that the alert matches the line-height of it’s parent container.

Nesting a form validation message within a .modal-footer is one example of this use-case.

Please sign in

Please enter your password. 
<div role="alert" class="alert alert-error alert-sm fade" aria-live="assertive">...</div>

Block alerts

For longer messages, increase the padding on the top and bottom of the alert wrapper by adding .alert-block.

            <div class="modal-header">

                    <i class="sr-only">Close</i>
                </button>

            </div>

                <div class="body-content">

Variations

Modal dialogs are very flexible components that have various size, callout and user action variations.

Size variation: Small

When a dialog doesn’t have very much content, Add the .modal-sm class to your modal to apply a more appropriately proportioned visual treatment.

Small Modal with Two Choices

Paragraph contents of a small modal dialog.

<div role="dialog" id="{{ modal-id }}" class="modal modal-sm fade"
     tabindex="-1"
     aria-hidden="true"
     aria-labelledby="{{ modal-title-id }}">
    ...
    <div class="modal-actions modal-footer">
      <button class="btn btn- btn-sm" data-dismiss="modal">...</button>
      <button class="btn btn- btn-sm">...</button>
    </div>
</div>
SublimeText Snippet:   wdesk-modal:sm  + tab Installation of the Web Skin SublimeText Snippets Package is required.

Use matching size variation for modal buttons

When placing buttons inside a .modal-sm size variation, be sure to use the .btn-sm size variation for appropriate action area affordance.

Callout dialog variation

When a modal dialog contains a singular call-to-action (like a confirmation dialog), add the .modal-callout class to your modal and omit the .modal-title element from .modal-header to emphasize the call-to-action messaging.

Optionally, add some iconography / imaging to provide the user with visual cues regarding the callout.

Actions variation: Unrelated

Use case examples

Modal dialogs have many use-cases within Wdesk apps. Some commonly used patterns are shown below.

Modal example: Session timeout

Wdesk’s session timeout messaging is delivered to users via a modal dialog using horizontal form-control and alert dialog components within a small modal dialog.

Welcome back Wdesk user

Please enter your password to sign back in.
Your password was incorrect. Please try again. 
<!-- (assume .modal-content nested within .modal > .modal-dialog) -->
<form class="modal-content" data-ng-submit="submitForm()">
  <div class="modal-header">
    <h3 class="modal-title" id="{{ modal-title-id }}">
      Welcome back Wdesk user
    </h3>
  </div>
  <div class="modal-body">
    <div class="body-content flush">
      <fieldset class="form-horizontal">
        <legend class="text-center">
          <em class="sub-legend">
            Please enter your password to sign back in
          </em>
        </legend>

        <!-- use grid patterns like 3|6|3 or 2|8|2
             to ensure input is horizontally centered. -->
        <div class="form-group" data-ng-class="{'has-error': invalidPassword || noPassword}">
          <label class="col-xs-3 control-label required"
                 for="enterPasswordField">
            Password:
          </label>
          <span class="col-xs-6">
            <input type="password" id="enterPasswordField"
                   class="form-control"
                   autocomplete="off"
                   aria-required="true"
                   required>
          </span>
        </div>
      </fieldset>
    </div>
  </div>
  <div class="modal-actions modal-footer">
    <div class="col-xs-10 flush-left validation-message-block">
      <div role="alert" class="alert alert-error fade"
           data-ng-class="{'in': invalidPassword || noPassword}"
           aria-live="assertive">
        <strong>Your password was incorrect. Please try again.</strong>
      </div>
    </div>
    <div class="col-xs-2 flush-left flush-right">
      <button type="submit" class="btn btn-block btn-primary">Sign in</button>
    </div>
  </div>
</form>

Opaque Modal Backdrop

The Session Timeout Modal Dialog example above makes use of the .opaque CSS utility class used on the .backdrop element to prevent the contents of the page from being displayed when a user's session has expired. This class can be added by customizing the backdropClass option via our Modal JS plugin.

This is a visual treatment only - used to indicate that they are logged out - and does not take the place of appropriate security measures that should be taken to prevent someone from gaining access to the DOM contents that may still be present.

Modal example: Notifications

Nest alert dialogs within a .modal-actions.modal-alert block to notify the user that something is happening within the context of the current dialog.

    <div class="modal-header">...</div>
    <div class="modal-actions modal-alert">
        <div role="alert" class="alert alert-error" aria-live="assertive">
            <i class="icon icon-blocked"></i>
            Error message appears here
        </div>
    </div>
    <div class="modal-body">...</div>
</div>

<!-- warning NOTIFICATION -->
<div class="modal-content">
    <div class="modal-header">...</div>
    <div class="modal-actions modal-alert">
        <div role="alert" class="alert alert-warning" aria-live="assertive">
            <i class="icon icon-warning-sign"></i>
            Warning message appears here
        </div>
    </div>
    <div class="modal-body">...</div>
</div>

<!-- informative NOTIFICATION -->
<div class="modal-content">
    <div class="modal-header">...</div>
    <div class="modal-actions modal-alert">
        <div role="alert" class="alert alert-alt" aria-live="polite">
            <i class="icon icon-info-sign"></i>
            Informative message appears here
        </div>
    </div>
    <div class="modal-body">...</div>
</div>

<!-- success NOTIFICATION -->

    <div class="modal-header">...</div>
    <div class="modal-actions modal-alert">
        <div role="alert" class="alert alert-success" aria-live="polite">
            <i class="icon icon-checkmark-sign-outline"></i>
            Success message appears here
        </div>
    </div>
    <div class="modal-body">...</div>
</div>
SublimeText Snippet:   wdesk-modal:notification:{variation}  + tab Installation of the Web Skin SublimeText Snippets Package is required.

Modal example: Product tour

Introduce users to new features in a release of your Wdesk app by using the Modal Product Tour pattern, powered by the Web Skin Carousel plugin. Try to use no more than five images within a single tour to keep things pithy for your users.

Accessible Carousel Markup

Take note of the carousel markup shown in this section as it is essential to ensure that your component is compliant according to WCAG 2.0.

Read More: Carousel Markup Accessibility

Custom CSS required

In order to hide the page indicators to make room for the “Get Started” button as shown in the example below, the CSS shown in the CSS tab below should be used.

  1. Slide #1
  2. Slide #2
  3. Slide #3
  4. Slide #4

Any other files you open will appear in the file editor tab.
