<!-- NESTED WITHIN A .modal-body elem -->
<div id="carousel-example-captions" class="carousel slide"
     data-interval="false"
     data-wrap="false">
    <!-- Page Indicators -->
    <ol role="menu" class="page-indicators">
        <li role="menuitemradio" data-target="#carousel-example-captions"
            data-slide-to="0"
            aria-checked="true"
            class="active">
            <i class="sr-only">Slide #1</i>
        </li>
        <li role="menuitemradio" data-target="#carousel-example-captions"
            data-slide-to="1"
            aria-checked="false">
            <i class="sr-only">Slide #2</i>
        </li>
        ...
    </ol>

    <!-- Wrapper for slides -->
    <div role="listbox" class="carousel-inner">
        <div role="option" class="item active" tabindex="0"
             aria-labelledby="carousel-example-captions-caption-0"
             aria-selected="true">
            <img src="..." alt="...">
            <div class="carousel-caption">
                <p id="carousel-example-captions-caption-0" class="lead">
                    ...
                </p>
            </div>
        </div>
        ...
        <div role="option" class="item" tabindex="-1"
             aria-labelledby="carousel-example-captions-caption-1"
             aria-selected="false">
            <img src="..." alt="...">
            <div class="carousel-caption">
                <p id="carousel-example-captions-caption-1" class="lead">
                    ...
                </p>
                <!-- Give them a clear way-out on the last slide -->
                <button type="button" class="btn btn-primary"
                        data-dismiss="modal">
                    Get Started
                </button>
            </div>
        </div>
    </div>

    <!-- Prev/Next Controls -->
    <div role="button" tabindex="0" class="hitarea left carousel-control"
            data-target="#carousel-example-captions"
            data-slide="prev">
        <i class="icon icon-carousel-prev icon-lg"></i>
        <i class="sr-only">Previous</i>
    </div>
    <div role="button" tabindex="0" class="hitarea right carousel-control"
            data-target="#carousel-example-captions"
            data-slide="next">
        <i class="icon icon-carousel-next icon-lg"></i>
        <i class="sr-only">Next</i>
    </div>
</div>
/*
    Hide the page indicators on the last slide
    to make room for the "Get Started" button
*/
.carousel.at-right-edge .page-indicators {
    display: none;
}
/* Give the "Get Started" button some room */
.carousel-caption .btn {
    margin-top: 8px;
}

Modal accessibility

Take note of the modal dialog markup shown in this section as it is essential to ensure that your component is compliant according to WCAG 2.0.

  1. Add role="dialog", tabindex="-1" and aria-hidden="true" to your primary .modal element
  2. Add aria-labelledby to your primary .modal element referencing the ID of your .modal-title element
  3. Add role="document" to the .modal-dialog elem so that NVDA can force document mode and read contents inside the modal dialog
  4. Use descriptive text inside the .close button using the .sr-only helper class
  5. Additionally, you may give a description of your modal dialog. Use the aria-describedby attribute in your primary .modal element to point to the description.
<div role="dialog" id="{{ modal-id }}" class="modal fade"
         tabindex="-1"
         aria-hidden="true"
         aria-labelledby="{{ modal-title-id }}"
         aria-describedby="{{ optional-modal-desc-id }}">
        <div role="document" class="modal-dialog">
            <div class="modal-content">
                <div class="modal-header">
                    <button type="button" class="close" data-dismiss="modal">
                        <i aria-hidden="true">&times;</i>
                        <i class="sr-only">Close</i>
                    </button>
                    <h4 id="{{ modal-title-id }}" class="modal-title">
                        Modal title
                    </h4>
                </div>
                <div id="{{ optional-modal-desc-id }}" class="modal-body">
                    ...
                </div>
            </div>
        </div>
    </div>
Related:  Modal JS Plugin Accessibility

Datepicker Dialogs

A component to enable Wdesk users to choose a date, or a range of dates from a calendar UI widget using our datepicker JS plugin.

Text input datepicker type

<input type="text" class="form-control" placeholder="Enter a date"
       data-provide="datepicker">

Component datepicker type

<div class="input-group date" data-provide="datepicker">
    <input type="text" class="form-control" placeholder="Enter a date">
    <span class="input-group-addon">
        <i class="icon icon-calendar"></i>
    </span>
</div>

Range datepicker type

to 
<div class="input-group input-daterange" data-provide="datepicker">
    <input type="text" class="form-control" placeholder="Start date">
    <span class="input-group-addon">to</span>
    <input type="text" class="form-control" placeholder="End date">
</div>

Embedded / Inline datepicker type

<div data-provide="datepicker-inline"></div>

Additional Options & Configurations

The above examples are just the “stock” options for the datepicker component. Check out the interactive datepicker configurator in the Javascript section of the docs for even more possibilities.

Progress

Provide up-to-date feedback on the progress of a workflow or action with simple yet flexible progress components.

Cross-browser compatibility

Progress bars and spinners use CSS3 transitions and animations to achieve some of their effects. These features are not supported in MSIE 9 and below or older versions of Firefox. Web Skin uses animated .gif image fallbacks for the unsupported effects.

Progress bars

Basic

<div class="progress">
    <div class="progress-bar" style="width: 60%;"></div>
</div>
SublimeText Snippet:   wdesk-progress-bar  + tab Installation of the Web Skin SublimeText Snippets Package is required.

Size variations

Add the progress-sm or progress-xs size variation class to your <div class="progress"> element to adjust the height / padding of the progress bar component.

Default Size

Small

Extra Small

<div class="progress">...</div>
<div class="progress-sm">...</div>
<div class="progress-xs">...</div>

Color variations

Progress bars use the same state classes that buttons do so your can use color to provide additional progress context to your users.

<div class="progress">
    <div class="progress-bar progress-bar-alt"></div>
</div>
<div class="progress">
    <div class="progress-bar progress-bar-success"></div>
</div>
<div class="progress">
    <div class="progress-bar progress-bar-warning"></div>
</div>
<div class="progress">
    <div class="progress-bar progress-bar-error"></div>
</div>

Indeterminate State

Add .indeterminate to the progress elem to make the bar go 100% width to indicate an "indeterminate" amount of time remaining.

You can also use a .progress-label element to keep your users informed in the case there is an indeterminate state involved.

Processing… 
<div class="progress indeterminate">
    <div class="progress-bar progress-bar-success"></div>
    <span class="progress-label">Processing&hellip;</span>
</div>
SublimeText Snippet:   wdesk-progress-bar:indeterminate  + tab Installation of the Web Skin SublimeText Snippets Package is required.

Stacked

Place multiple bars into the same .progress to stack them.

<div class="progress">
    <div class="progress-bar progress-bar-success" style="width: 35%"></div>
    <div class="progress-bar progress-bar-warning" style="width: 20%"></div>
    <div class="progress-bar progress-bar-error" style="width: 10%"></div>
</div>

App Loading Progress

Below is the specification for a loading screen to display to your users when your application is first loading.

Click here to view a full-screen example

Loading…

Copyright © 2015 Workiva. All Rights Reserved.

<div class="app-loading-content">
    <div class="app-loading-logo block-center">
        <img src="assets/img/brand/wdesk-logo_color.svg" alt="Wdesk" >
    </div>
    <div class="progress indeterminate block-center">
        <div class="progress-bar progress-bar-success"></div>
        <span class="progress-label">Loading&hellip;</span>
    </div>
</div>
<div class="app-loading-copyright">
    <p class="text-center">Copyright &copy; {{ now.year }} Workiva. All Rights Reserved.</p>
</div>

Cross-browser compatibility

The SVG image used in the above example will not work in MSIE 8 and below. If your app needs to support MSIE 7 & 8, add the onerror attribute to the <img> tag as shown below.

<img src="assets/img/brand/wdesk-logo_color.svg"
     onerror="this.onerror=null; this.src='assets/img/brand/wdesk-logo_color_retina.png'"
     alt="Wdesk">


Check out David Bushell’s article for more information on this workaround.

Progress spinners

Basic

<i class="progress-spinner"></i>
SublimeText Snippet:   wdesk-progress-spinner  + tab Installation of the Web Skin SublimeText Snippets Package is required.

Size variations

Progress spinners use built-in utility size classes to make it fit your layout just-right.

<i class="progress-spinner progress-spinner-md"></i>
<i class="progress-spinner"></i>
<i class="progress-spinner progress-spinner-huge"></i>
<i class="progress-spinner progress-spinner-gigantic"></i>

Inverse color variation

To use a light-colored spinner on a colored/dark background, add the progress-spinner-inverse CSS class to your .progress-spinner elem.

<i class="progress-spinner progress-spinner-inverse"></i>

Adding labels

Wrap your progress spinner in a .progress-spinner-container element and add a .progress-label. Optionally, you can add .progress-spinner-stacked to the container element to center the spinner and label with the label appear below the spinner.

Default

Loading

Stacked

Loading 
<!-- DEFAULT -->
<div class="progress-spinner-container">
    <i class="progress-spinner"></i>
    <span class="progress-label">Loading</span>
</div>
<!-- STACKED VARIATION -->
<div class="progress-spinner-container progress-spinner-stacked">
    <i class="progress-spinner"></i>
    <span class="progress-label">Loading</span>
</div>

Spinner labels adapt to size variations

Simply add one of the built-in size variation classes to the spinner, and the label size / spacing will adjust accordingly.

Default

Loading
Loading
Loading

Stacked

Loading
Loading
Loading 
<!-- DEFAULT -->
<div class="progress-spinner-container">
    <i class="progress-spinner progress-spinner-md"></i>
    <span class="progress-label">Loading</span>
</div>
<!-- STACKED VARIATION -->
<div class="progress-spinner-container progress-spinner-stacked">
    <i class="progress-spinner progress-spinner-md"></i>
    <span class="progress-label">Loading</span>
</div>

Use along with downloading icon glyphs

The spinners are built to work alongside the other icon glyphs that are related to the act of downloading / refreshing. Spinners in this situation should be implemented using .icon .icon-downloading.

JS plugin example

The example below was built using our buttons plugin - the code example below simply shows the three icon classes and how they complement the appearance of our progress spinner.

<!-- DOWNLOAD AVAILABLE STATE -->
<button type="button" class="btn text-left">
    <span class="btn-text">Download</span>
    <i class="icon icon-md icon-two-color icon-download-available"></i>
</button>

<!-- DOWNLOADING STATE (USING SPINNER) -->
<button type="button" class="btn text-left">
    <span class="btn-text">Downloading</span>
    <i class="... icon-downloading"></i>
</button>

<!-- DOWNLOADED STATE -->
<button type="button" class="btn text-left">
    <span class="btn-text">View File</span>
    <i class="... icon-downloaded"></i>
</button>

Thumbnails

Extend Web Skin’s grid system with the thumbnail component to easily display grids of images, videos, text, and more.

Default example

By default, Web Skin’s thumbnails are designed to showcase linked images with minimal required markup.

<div class="row">
    <div class="col-xs-6 col-md-3">
        <a href="#" class="thumbnail">
            <img data-src="holder.js/100%x180" alt="...">
        </a>
    </div>
    ...
</div>

Custom content

With a bit of extra markup, it’s possible to add any kind of HTML content like headings, paragraphs, or buttons into thumbnails.

Thumbnail label

Cras justo odio, dapibus ac facilisis in, egestas eget quam. Donec id elit non mi porta gravida at eget metus. Nullam id dolor id nibh ultricies vehicula ut id elit.

Button Button

Thumbnail label

Cras justo odio, dapibus ac facilisis in, egestas eget quam. Donec id elit non mi porta gravida at eget metus. Nullam id dolor id nibh ultricies vehicula ut id elit.

Button Button

Thumbnail label

Cras justo odio, dapibus ac facilisis in, egestas eget quam. Donec id elit non mi porta gravida at eget metus. Nullam id dolor id nibh ultricies vehicula ut id elit.

Button Button

<div class="row">
    <div class="col-sm-6 col-md-4">
        <div class="thumbnail">
            <img data-src="holder.js/100%x200" alt="...">
            <div class="caption">
                <h3>Thumbnail label</h3>
                <p>...</p>
                <p><a href="#" class="btn btn-alt" role="button">Button</a> <a href="#" class="btn btn-default" role="button">Button</a></p>
            </div>
        </div>
    </div>
</div>

Media object

Abstract object styles for building various types of components that feature a left or right-aligned image alongside textual content.

Default media

The default media allow to float a media object (images, video, audio) to the left or right of a content block.

Media heading

Cras sit amet nibh libero, in gravida nulla. Nulla vel metus scelerisque ante sollicitudin commodo. Cras purus odio, vestibulum in vulputate at, tempus viverra turpis. Fusce condimentum nunc ac nisi vulputate fringilla. Donec lacinia congue felis in faucibus.

Media heading

Cras sit amet nibh libero, in gravida nulla. Nulla vel metus scelerisque ante sollicitudin commodo. Cras purus odio, vestibulum in vulputate at, tempus viverra turpis. Fusce condimentum nunc ac nisi vulputate fringilla. Donec lacinia congue felis in faucibus.

Media heading

Cras sit amet nibh libero, in gravida nulla. Nulla vel metus scelerisque ante sollicitudin commodo. Cras purus odio, vestibulum in vulputate at, tempus viverra turpis. Fusce condimentum nunc ac nisi vulputate fringilla. Donec lacinia congue felis in faucibus. 
<div class="media">
    <a class="pull-left" href="#">
        <img class="media-object" src="..." alt="...">
    </a>
    <div class="media-body">
        <h4 class="media-heading">Media heading</h4>
        ...
    </div>
</div>
SublimeText Snippet:   wdesk-media:object  + tab Installation of the Web Skin SublimeText Snippets Package is required.

Media list

With a bit of extra markup, you can use media inside list (useful for comment threads or articles lists).

  • Media heading

List group

List groups are a flexible and powerful component for displaying not only simple lists of elements, but complex ones with custom content.

Basic example

The most basic list group is simply an unordered list with list items, and the proper classes. Build upon it with the options that follow, or your own CSS as needed.

Default

  • Cras justo odio
  • Dapibus ac facilisis in
  • Morbi leo risus
  • Porta ac consectetur ac
  • Vestibulum at eros

Bordered

  • Cras justo odio
  • Dapibus ac facilisis in
  • Morbi leo risus
  • Porta ac consectetur ac
  • Vestibulum at eros
<ul class="list-group">
    <li class="list-group-item">Cras justo odio</li>
    <li class="list-group-item">Dapibus ac facilisis in</li>
    <li class="list-group-item">Morbi leo risus</li>
    <li class="list-group-item">Porta ac consectetur ac</li>
    <li class="list-group-item">Vestibulum at eros</li>
</ul>

<ul class="list-group list-group-bordered">
    ...
</ul>

Badges

Add the badges component to any list group item and it will automatically be positioned on the right.

  • 14 Cras justo odio
  • 2 Dapibus ac facilisis in
  • 1 Morbi leo risus

    <li class="list-group-item">

        Cras justo odio
    </li>
</ul>

Linked items

Linkify list group items by using a clickable element instead of list items and adding the .hitarea class. (that also means a parent <div> instead of an <ul>). No need for individual parents around each element.

Default

Cras justo odio Dapibus ac facilisis in Morbi leo risus Porta ac consectetur ac

Bordered

Cras justo odio Dapibus ac facilisis in Morbi leo risus Porta ac consectetur ac 
<div class="list-group">
    <a href="#" class="hitarea list-group-item active">
        Cras justo odio
    </a>
    <a href="#" class="hitarea list-group-item">Dapibus ac facilisis in</a>
    <a href="#" class="hitarea list-group-item">Morbi leo risus</a>
    <a href="#" class="hitarea list-group-item">Porta ac consectetur ac</a>
    <button type="button" class="hitarea list-group-item"
            data-ng-click="doSomething()">
        Vestibulum at eros
    </button>
</div>

<div class="list-group list-group-bordered">
    ...
</div>
SublimeText Snippet:   wdesk-list-group:linked  + tab Installation of the Web Skin SublimeText Snippets Package is required.

Panels

While not always necessary, sometimes you need to put your DOM in a box. For those situations, try the panel component.

Basic example

By default, all the .panel does is apply some basic border and padding to contain some content.

Basic panel example 
<div class="panel panel-default">
    <div class="panel-body">
        Basic panel example
    </div>
</div>

Panel with heading

Easily add a heading container to your panel with .panel-heading. You may also include any <h1>-<h6> with a .panel-title class to add a pre-styled heading.

Panel content

Panel focus

To draw attention to a specific panel in your layout, add .panel-focus to provide affordance indicating that the user should be interacting within that particular panel.

Optionally, you can add this focus styling automatically on :hover and :focus by using .panel-hover instead.

Collapsible panels

Easily make a set of related panels expand and collapse by wrapping them in a .panel-group, and a little help from our collapse plugin.

General

Legend

Some default panel content here. Nulla vitae elit libero, a pharetra augue. Aenean lacinia bibendum nulla sed consectetur. Aenean eu leo quam. Pellentesque ornare sem lacinia quam venenatis vestibulum. Nullam id dolor id nibh ultricies vehicula ut id elit.

Axis

Some default panel content here. Nulla vitae elit libero, a pharetra augue. Aenean lacinia bibendum nulla sed consectetur. Aenean eu leo quam. Pellentesque ornare sem lacinia quam venenatis vestibulum. Nullam id dolor id nibh ultricies vehicula ut id elit.

<div role="presentation" class="panel-group">
    <div role="presentation" class="panel panel-default">
        <div role="button" class="panel-heading open" tabindex="0"
             aria-selected="true"
             aria-expanded="true"
             aria-controls="general"
             data-target="#general"
             data-toggle="collapse">
            <h3 id="general-title" class="panel-title">General</h3>
            <i class="caret" aria-hidden="true"></i>
        </div>
        <div id="general" class="panel panel-collapse collapse in"
             tabindex="-1"
             aria-hidden="true"
             aria-labelledby="general-title">
            <div class="panel-body">
                ...
            </div>
        </div>
    </div>
    <div role="presentation" class="panel panel-default">
        <div role="button" class="panel-heading" tabindex="0"
             aria-selected="false"
             aria-expanded="false"
             aria-controls="legend"
             data-target="#legend"
             data-toggle="collapse">
            <h3 id="legend-title" class="panel-title">Legend</h3>
            <i class="caret" aria-hidden="true"></i>
        </div>
        <div id="legend" class="panel panel-collapse collapse"
             tabindex="-1"
             aria-hidden="true"
             aria-labelledby="legend-title">
            <div class="panel-body">
                ...
            </div>
        </div>
    </div>
    <div role="presentation" class="panel panel-default">
        <div role="button" class="panel-heading" tabindex="0"
             aria-selected="false"
             aria-expanded="false"
             aria-controls="axis"
             data-target="#axis"
             data-toggle="collapse">
            <h3 id="axis-title" class="panel-title">Axis</h3>
            <i class="caret" aria-hidden="true"></i>
        </div>
        <div id="axis" class="panel panel-collapse collapse" tabindex="-1"
             aria-hidden="true"
             aria-labelledby="axis-title">
            <div class="panel-body">
                ...
            </div>
        </div>
    </div>
</div>

Collapsible panel accessibility

Take note of the collapsing panel markup shown in this section as it is essential to ensure that your component is compliant according to WCAG 2.0.

Related:  Collapse JS Plugin Accessibility

Panel wrappers

  1. Add role="presentation" to the .panel-group element
  2. Add role="presentation" to each .panel-group > .panel element
<div role="presentation" class="panel-group">
        <div role="presentation" class="panel">
            ...
        </div>
        <div role="presentation" class="panel">
            ...
        </div>
        <div role="presentation" class="panel">
            ...
        </div>
    </div>

All panels

Panel heading element:
  1. Add attributes role="button", tabindex="-1", aria-selected="false" and aria-expanded="false"
  2. Add aria-controls attribute with a value equal to the ID of the .panel-collapse element that it controls
  3. Add a unique ID to the .panel-title element so the associated .panel-collapse element can use it in it’s aria-labelledby attribute
  4. Add aria-hidden="true" to the .caret element
Panel content element:
  1. Add attributes tabindex="-1" and aria-hidden="true"
  2. Add a unique ID so the associated .panel-heading can use it in it’s aria-controls attribute
  3. Add aria-labelledby attribute with a value equal to the ID of the .panel-title element within the .panel-heading that controls it
<div role="presentation" class="panel">
        <div role="button" class="panel-heading" tabindex="-1"
             aria-selected="false"
             aria-expanded="false"
             aria-controls="{{ panel-collapse-id }}">
            <h3 id="{{ panel-title-id }}" class="panel-title">Panel Title</h3>
            <i class="caret" aria-hidden="true"></i>
        </div>
        <div id="{{ panel-collapse-id }}" class="panel panel-collapse"
             tabindex="-1"
             aria-hidden="true"
             aria-labelledby="{{ panel-title-id }}">
            ...
        </div>
    </div>

Initially expanded panel

The collapse JS plugin will handle the toggling of these attributes when panels are expanded/collapsed dynamically. However, for the initial state of your group of collapsible panels, if you have a panel that is expanded, set the attributes as described below.

Panel heading element:
  1. Change tabindex attribute value to 0
  2. Change aria-selected and aria-expanded attribute values to true
Panel content element:
  1. Change tabindex attribute value to 0
  2. Change aria-hidden attribute value to false
<div role="presentation" class="panel">
        <div role="button" class="panel-heading" tabindex="0"
             aria-selected="true"
             aria-expanded="true"
             aria-controls="{{ panel-collapse-id }}">
            <h3 id="{{ panel-title-id }}" class="panel-title">Panel Title</h3>
            <i class="caret" aria-hidden="true"></i>
        </div>
        <div id="{{ panel-collapse-id }}" class="panel panel-collapse"
             tabindex="0"
             aria-hidden="false"
             aria-labelledby="{{ panel-title-id }}">
            ...
        </div>
    </div>

Additional markup required for collapse data-api

The collapsing panel component attributes listed above pertain only to accessibility - not the dynamic data-api functionality of the component. Please reference the collapse data-api documentation to ensure all the required data-api attributes are present in your implementation.

Accordion panels

Use the collapse plugin’s parent option along with a wrapper element around the .panel-group to make a set of mututally exclusive panels behave like a traditional accordion UI widget.

General

Legend

Some default panel content here. Nulla vitae elit libero, a pharetra augue. Aenean lacinia bibendum nulla sed consectetur. Aenean eu leo quam. Pellentesque ornare sem lacinia quam venenatis vestibulum. Nullam id dolor id nibh ultricies vehicula ut id elit.

Axis

Some default panel content here. Nulla vitae elit libero, a pharetra augue. Aenean lacinia bibendum nulla sed consectetur. Aenean eu leo quam. Pellentesque ornare sem lacinia quam venenatis vestibulum. Nullam id dolor id nibh ultricies vehicula ut id elit.

<div role="tablist" id="panel-accordion" aria-multiselectable="true">
    <div role="presentation" class="panel-group">
        <div role="presentation" class="panel panel-default">
            <div role="tab" class="panel-heading open" tabindex="0"
                 aria-selected="true"
                 aria-expanded="true"
                 aria-controls="general"
                 data-target="#general"
                 data-toggle="collapse"
                 data-parent="#panel-accordion">
                <h3 id="general-title" class="panel-title">General</h3>
                <i class="caret" aria-hidden="true"></i>
            </div>
            <div role="tabpanel" id="general" class="panel panel-collapse collapse in"
                 tabindex="0"
                 aria-labelledby="general-title"
                 aria-hidden="false">
                <div class="panel-body">
                    ...
                </div>
            </div>
        </div>
        <div role="presentation" class="panel panel-default">
            <div role="tab" class="panel-heading collapsed" tabindex="-1"
                 aria-selected="false"
                 aria-expanded="false"
                 aria-controls="legend"
                 data-target="#legend"
                 data-toggle="collapse"
                 data-parent="#panel-accordion">
                <h3 id="legend-title" class="panel-title">Legend</h3>
                <i class="caret" aria-hidden="true"></i>
            </div>
            <div role="tabpanel" id="legend" class="panel panel-collapse collapse"
                 tabindex="-1"
                 aria-labelledby="legend-title"
                 aria-hidden="true">
                <div class="panel-body">
                    ...
                </div>
            </div>
        </div>
        <div role="presentation" class="panel panel-default">
            <div role="tab" class="panel-heading collapsed" tabindex="-1"
                 aria-selected="false"
                 aria-expanded="false"
                 aria-controls="axis"
                 data-target="#axis"
                 data-toggle="collapse"
                 data-parent="#panel-accordion">
                <h3 id="axis-title" class="panel-title">Axis</h3>
                <i class="caret" aria-hidden="true"></i>
            </div>
            <div role="tabpanel" id="axis" class="panel panel-collapse collapse"
                 tabindex="-1"
                 aria-labelledby="axis-title"
                 aria-hidden="true">
                <div class="panel-body">
                    ...
                </div>
            </div>
        </div>
    </div>
</div>

Accordion panel accessibility

Take note of the accordion panel markup shown in this section as it is essential to ensure that your component is compliant according to WCAG 2.0.

Related:  Collapse JS Plugin Accessibility

Panel wrappers

  1. Add a unique ID, role="tablist" and aria-multiselectable="true" to the element identified as parent via the collapse plugin parent option
    1. The aria-multiselectable attribute tells screen readers that the data-toggle="collapse" elems in the group can control more than one tabpanel with a single click/keypress in order to ensure that one panel remains visible at any given time
  2. Add role="presentation" to each .panel-group and .panel-group > .panel element
<div role="tablist" id="{{ parent-tablist-id }}" aria-multiselectable="true">
        <div role="presentation" class="panel-group">
            <div role="presentation" class="panel">
                ...
            </div>
            <div role="presentation" class="panel">
                ...
            </div>
            <div role="presentation" class="panel">
                ...
            </div>
        </div>
    </div>

All panels

Panel heading element:
  1. Add attributes role="tab", tabindex="-1", aria-selected="false" and aria-expanded="false"
  2. Add aria-controls attribute with a value equal to the ID of the tabpanel that it controls
  3. Add a unique ID to the .panel-title element so the associated tabpanel can use it in it’s aria-labelledby attribute
  4. Add aria-hidden="true" to the .caret element
Panel content element:
  1. Add attributes role="tabpanel", tabindex="-1" and aria-hidden="true"
  2. Add a unique ID so the associated .panel-heading can use it in it’s aria-controls attribute
  3. Add aria-labelledby attribute with a value equal to the ID of the .panel-title element within the .panel-heading that controls it
<div role="presentation" class="panel">
        <div role="tab" class="panel-heading" tabindex="-1"
             aria-selected="false"
             aria-expanded="false"
             aria-controls="{{ panel-collapse-id }}">
            <h3 id="{{ panel-title-id }}" class="panel-title">Panel Title</h3>
            <i class="caret" aria-hidden="true"></i>
        </div>
        <div role="tabpanel" id="{{ panel-collapse-id }}" class="panel panel-collapse"
             tabindex="-1"
             aria-hidden="true"
             aria-labelledby="{{ panel-title-id }}">
            ...
        </div>
    </div>

Initially expanded panel

The collapse JS plugin will handle the toggling of these attributes when panels are expanded/collapsed dynamically. However, for the initial state of your accordion, if you have a panel that is expanded, set the attributes as described below.

Panel heading element:
  1. Change tabindex attribute value to 0
  2. Change aria-selected and aria-expanded attribute values to true
Panel content element:
  1. Change tabindex attribute value to 0
  2. Change aria-hidden attribute value to false
<div role="presentation" class="panel">
        <div role="tab" class="panel-heading" tabindex="0"
             aria-selected="true"
             aria-expanded="true"
             aria-controls="{{ panel-collapse-id }}">
            <h3 id="{{ panel-title-id }}" class="panel-title">Panel Title</h3>
            <i class="caret" aria-hidden="true"></i>
        </div>
        <div role="tabpanel" id="{{ panel-collapse-id }}" class="panel panel-collapse"
             tabindex="0"
             aria-hidden="false"
             aria-labelledby="{{ panel-title-id }}">
            ...
        </div>
    </div>

Additional markup required for collapse data-api

The accordion panel component attributes listed above pertain only to accessibility - not the dynamic data-api functionality of the component. Please reference the collapse data-api documentation to ensure all the required data-api attributes are present in your implementation.

Global Jobs Panel

Keep your user informed with a collapsible panel containing all the current “jobs” that the app is currently working on.

Requires Web Skin Collapse Plugin

In order to expand/minimize the jobs panel, your application must include our Collapse plugin.

Custom JS Required for handling jobs panel view states

In order to control the view state of the panel, it’s heading, and the jobs within the panel - manipulate the CSS classes on the .panel, .panel-title icon and .job-item elems, respectively. In our example markup below - the classes necessary to reflect each view state are shown in sudo-angular data-ng-class attribute logic. You are free to implement this logic however you see fit in your application, but the CSS classes are not optional.

Have questions about this view state logic? give us a shout or open a new issue.

Custom JS Required for handling row click event(s)

Note that you would actually have to wire up the data-ng-click via AngularJS (or any other JS library you’re using) on each completed job-row for the Open/Retry actions to actually be triggered when the row is clicked.

Use the tabs below to toggle between the different view states.

  • Job(s) In Progress
  • Jobs Done (success)
  • Jobs Done (errors)

Panel Comments

HTML Markup Demonstrates View State

The markup for panel comments is highly dynamic, so we’re illustrating the dynamic CSS classes and elements shown below using pseudo-AngularJS markup. Obviously, to wire up this functionality in your application, you'll need to toggle these classes and elements according to actual logic.

We’ve done our best to demonstrate the intent of the interactions according to UX specification. However, if you have questions, or find flaws with the logic demonstrated here, please reach out to us via HipChat or Github so we can help.

Our platform is intended to save you time - not become an obstruction.

<div class="panel-group panel-hover panel-comments-thread comments">
  <div class="panel panel-default panel-condensed comment panel-comment"
       data-ng-repeat="comment in comments">

    <div class="panel-heading comment-header navbar">

      <h3 class="panel-title comment-title">
        <i class="icon icon-comment-checkmark text-green"></i>
        {{ commentAuthorName }}
      </h3>

      <div class="comment-meta pull-right">
        <small class="comment-timestamp">
          {{ timeago(date.now) }}
        </small>
      </div>

      <!-- IF: comment.initiatesThread -->
      <div class="thread-collapse-control"
           data-ng-if="comment.initiatesThread"></div>

      <ul role="menu" class="nav nav-tabs nav-secondary thread-actions"
          data-ng-if="comment.initiatesThread">
        <li class="dropdown">
          <button type="button" class="hitarea dropdown-toggle no-text"
                  data-toggle="dropdown"
                  data-auto-width=true>
            <i class="icon icon-twfr-menu-list"></i>
          </button>
          <ul role="menu" class="dropdown-menu pull-right">
            <!-- THREAD ACTIONS -->
          </ul>
        </li>
      </ul>
      <!-- END IF: comment.initiatesThread -->

    </div>

    <div class="panel panel-collapse collapse in">

      <div class="panel-body">
        <div class="comment-body">
          <textarea class="form-control"></textarea>
        </div>
      </div>

      <div class="panel-footer panel-footer-vanilla comment-footer">
        <div class="comment-actions pull-right">
          <button type="button" class="btn btn-sm btn-link">
            Cancel
          </button>
          <button type="submit" class="btn btn-sm btn-primary">
            Post
          </button>
        </div>
      </div>

      <div class="backdrop comment-reply-edit-overlay">
        <button type="button" class="hitarea edit-comment-btn">
          <i class="icon icon-pencil"></i>
        </button>
        <i class="icon icon-reply"></i>
      </div>

      <div class="modal fade confirmation-modal">
        <!--
          comment confirmation modal content goes here
          NOTE: content should vary based on if its a reply or not
        -->
      </div>

    </div>

  </div> <!-- END COMMENT -->

  <div class="modal fade confirmation-modal">
    <!--
        comment thread confirmation modal content goes here
    -->
  </div>

<!--
  *** COMPLETE MARKUP w/ VIEW LOGIC ***
  Use tabs on the right to toggle between different markup options

  Be sure to check out the "Controller JS" example tab as well
  for examples of how the various pseudo-angular logic vars/methods
  are intended to behave according to UX specification.
-->

<div id="thread{{comment.thread.id}}"
     class="panel-group panel-hover panel-comments-thread comments"
     data-ng-class="{'panel-thread-closed': isThreadResolved,
                     'panel-thread-collapsed': isThreadCollapsed,
                     'comment-editing panel-focus': threadState == 'comment-editing',
                     'modal-open overlaid': threadState == 'comment-action-confirmation'
                    }">

  <div id="{{comment.id}}"
       class="panel panel-default panel-condensed comment panel-comment"
       data-ng-class="{'comment-editing': editingComment,
                       'comment-new': editingComment && !comment.isPosted(),
                       'comment-initial': comment.initiatesThread,
                       'comment-last': comment.isLastOrOnlyInThread()
                      }"
       data-ng-repeat="comment in comments">

    <div class="panel-heading comment-header navbar">

      <h3 class="panel-title comment-title">
        <i class="icon icon-comment-checkmark text-green"></i>
        {{ commentAuthorName }}
      </h3>

      <div class="comment-meta pull-right">
        <small class="comment-timestamp">
          {{ timeago(date.now) }}
        </small>
      </div>

      <!-- IF: comment.initiatesThread -->
      <div class="thread-collapse-control"
           data-ng-if="comment.initiatesThread"
           data-ng-click="collapseCommentThread({{comment.thread.id}}, {{comment.id}})">
      </div>

      <ul role="menu" class="nav nav-tabs nav-secondary thread-actions"
          data-ng-if="comment.initiatesThread">
        <li class="dropdown">
          <button type="button" class="hitarea dropdown-toggle no-text"
                  data-toggle="dropdown"
                  data-auto-width=true>
            <i class="icon icon-twfr-menu-list"></i>
          </button>
          <ul role="menu" class="dropdown-menu pull-right">
            <li role="presentation">
              <button type="button" class="hitarea"
                      data-toggle="modal"
                      data-parent-container=".panel-comments-thread"
                      data-container=".panel-comments-thread"
                      data-target="#thread{{comment.thread.id}}-confirmation-container">
                <i class="icon icon-trash"></i>
                Delete Comment<span ng-if="comments.length > 1"> Thread</span>
              </button>
            </li>
            <li role="presentation">
              <button type="button" class="hitarea"
                      data-ng-click="ResolveOrReopenThread({{comment.thread.id}})">
                <i class="icon"
                   data-ng-class="{'icon-comment-checkmark': !isThreadResolved,
                                   'icon-comment-reopen': isThreadResolved
                                  }"></i>
                {{ Resolve||Reopen }} Comment<span ng-if="comments.length > 1"> Thread</span>
              </button>
            </li>
          </ul>
        </li>
      </ul>
      <!-- END IF: comment.initiatesThread -->

    </div>

    <div id="{{comment.id}}-collapse" class="panel panel-collapse collapse in">

      <div class="panel-body">
        <div class="comment-body">
          <textarea class="form-control"
                    data-ng-readonly="!editingComment"
                    placeholder="{ 'Start typing&hellip;': !commentIsReply,
                                   'Reply to this comment&hellip;': commentIsReply
                                 }"></textarea>
        </div>
      </div>

      <div class="panel-footer panel-footer-vanilla comment-footer"
           data-ng-if="editingComment">
        <div class="comment-actions pull-right">
          <button type="button" class="btn btn-sm btn-link"
                  data-toggle="modal"
                  data-parent-container=".comment"
                  data-container=".comment"
                  data-target="#comment{{comment.id}}-confirmation-container">
            Cancel
          </button>
          <button type="submit" class="btn btn-sm btn-primary post"
                  data-ng-disabled="isCommentEmpty()"
                  disabled>
            Post
          </button>
        </div>
      </div>

      <div class="backdrop comment-reply-edit-overlay"
           data-ng-if="{ !isThreadResolved && !isThreadCollapsed &&
                         comment.isLastOrOnlyInThread()
                       }"
           data-ng-click="reply({{comment.thread.id}})"
           data-ng-hover="replyTooltip()"
           data-target="#replyTooltip">
        <button type="button" class="hitarea edit-comment-btn" title="Edit Comment"
                data-ng-if="user.canEditComment()"
                data-ng-click="edit({{comment.thread.id}}, {{comment.id}})"
                data-ng-hover="editTooltip()">
          <i class="icon icon-pencil"></i>
        </button>

        <i class="icon icon-reply"></i>
      </div>

      <div id="comment{{comment.id}}-confirmation-container"
           class="modal fade confirmation-modal">
        <!--
          comment confirmation modal content goes here
          NOTE: content should vary based on if its a reply or not
        -->
      </div>

    </div>

  </div> <!-- END COMMENT -->

  <div id="thread{{comment.thread.id}}-confirmation-container"
       class="modal fade confirmation-modal">
    <!--
        comment thread confirmation modal content goes here
    -->
  </div>

  <div id="thread{{comment.thread.id}}-overlay"
       class="backdrop thread-overlay"
       data-ng-if="isThreadResolved">
  </div>

</div> <!-- END COMMENT THREAD -->
// --------------------------------------------------------------------
//
// JS CONTROLLER SUGGESTIONS
//
//   + These example methods are ONLY SUGGESTIONS
//   + None of this JS logic is provided "out of the box" with Web Skin
//     except for the Web Skin JS plugin events like `shown.wdesk.collapse`, etc.
//
//  These methods are either
//   + how we suggest you leverage Web Skin plugin JS to implement in your project
//        - OR -
//   + how we implemented it in this demo
//
// --------------------------------------------------------------------


//
//
// Set thread state
//
// @since 0.4.5-1
// @param {guid}   threadId     Thread involved
// @param {string} state        New view state for the thread
//
//
function setThreadState (threadId, state) {
    // [assume this method knows what angular is]
    var $scope = angular.scope;

    $scope.threadState = state;
}


//
//
// Get thread state
//
// @since 0.4.5-1
// @param {guid}   threadId     Thread involved
// @returns {string}            The current thread state.
//
//
function getThreadState (threadId) {
    // [assume this method knows what angular is]
    var $scope = angular.scope;

    return $scope.threadState;
}


//
//
// When thread loads, wire up some thread logic
//
// @since 0.4.5-1
// @param {guid} threadId     Thread to be collapsed
//
//
function intializeThread (threadId) {
    // [assume this method knows what angular is]
    var $scope = angular.scope;
    var $thread = $('#thread' + threadId);

    //
    // When individual thread comment confirmation modals are shown/hidden,
    // set the state of the thread to 'comment-action-confirmation'
    //
    var $commentConfirmationModals = $('.comment > .modal', $thread);
    var previousThreadState;

    $commentConfirmationModals
        .on('shown.wdesk.modal', function (event) {
            previousThreadState = getThreadState(threadId);
            setThreadState(threadId, 'comment-action-confirmation');
        })
        .on('hidden.wdesk.modal', function (event) {
            // set back to whatever it was before showing the confirmation
            setThreadState(threadId, previousThreadState);
        });
}


//
//
// Resolve / Reopen Thread
//
// @since 0.4.5-1
// @param {guid} threadId    Thread involved
//
//
function ResolveOrReopenThread (threadId) {
    // [assume this method knows what angular is]
    var $scope = angular.scope;

    //
    // Toggle scope var that controls the "Resolved" status of a thread
    //
    $scope.isThreadResolved = !$scope.isThreadResolved;
}


//
//
// Control z-index of adjacent panel threads when thread actions menu is open
//
// This method should be called once when a thread is created
//
// @since 0.4.9-2
// @param {guid} threadId     Thread to be collapsed
//
//
function initThreadZindex (threadId) {
    // [assume this method knows what angular is]
    var $scope = angular.scope;

    var $thread = $('#' + threadId);
    var $threadMenuButton = $thread.find('.thread-actions > .dropdown');

    $threadMenuButton
        .on('show.wdesk.dropdown', function () {
            $thread.addClass('has-open-menu');
        })
        .on('hide.wdesk.dropdown', function () {
            $thread.removeClass('has-open-menu');
        });
}


//
//
// Collapse entire thread of comments when .thread-collapse-control is clicked
//
// @since 0.4.5-1
// @param {guid} threadId     Thread to be collapsed
// @param {guid} commentId    Initial (first) comment in the thread
//
//
function collapseCommentThread (threadId, commentId) {
    // [assume this method knows what angular is]
    var $scope = angular.scope;

    //
    // initialize collapse behavior of initial (first) comment in the thread
    // so we can wire up the collapse behavior of the subsequent
    // reply collapse wrappers using the collapse events it will broadcast.
    //
    var $initialCommentCollapseWrapper = $('#' + commentId + '-collapse');
    var initialized = $initialCommentCollapseWrapper.data('wdesk.collapse');
    !initialized && $initialCommentCollapseWrapper.collapse();

    //
    // locate replies within the thread
    //
    var $replyCommentCollapseWrappers =
        $('.panel-collapse', '#thread' + threadId).not($initialCommentCollapseWrapper);

    //
    // expand/collapse replies when initial comment does so
    //
    $initialCommentCollapseWrapper
        .on('hide.wdesk.collapse', function (event) {
            $replyCommentCollapseWrappers.collapse('hide');
        })
        .on('hidden.wdesk.collapse', function (event) {
            $scope.isThreadCollapsed = true;
        })
        .on('show.wdesk.collapse', function (event) {
            $replyCommentCollapseWrappers.collapse('show');
        })
        .on('shown.wdesk.collapse', function (event) {
            $scope.isThreadCollapsed = false;
        });
}


//
//
// Check collapse state of thread before showing delete confirmation modal
// *** this assumes that the button that triggers the confirmation modal is
// bound via the modal plugin's data-api (see complete HTML markup tab) ***
//
// @since 0.4.7
//
//
var $threadConfirmationModals = $('.panel-comments-thread').find(' > .confirmation-modal');
$threadConfirmationModals.on('show.wdesk.modal', function (event) {
    var $that = $(this),
        deleteThreadButtonClicked = event.relatedTarget;

    if (deleteThreadButtonClicked) {
        var $collapseTarget = $(event.relatedTarget.data('target'));
        var $threadWrapper = $collapseTarget.parent('.panel-comments-thread');
        var isCollapsed = $threadWrapper.hasClass('panel-thread-collapsed');
        if (isCollapsed) {
            // don't show confirmation modal yet
            event.preventDefault();

            // expand the collapsed thread
            var $initialCommentCollapseWrapper = $threadWrapper.find('> .panel:first .panel-collapse');
            $initialCommentCollapseWrapper
                // use .one() instead of .on() so that our
                // listener is automatically de-registered
                .one('shown.wdesk.collapse', function (event) {
                    // proceed with the modal confirmation now that its expanded
                    $that.modal('show');
                })
                .collapse('show');
        }
    }
});



//
//
// Edit existing comment
//
// @since 0.4.5-1
// @param {guid} threadId     Thread involved
// @param {guid} commentId    Comment to be edited
//
//
function edit (threadId, commentId) {
    // [assume this method knows what angular is]
    var $scope = angular.scope;

    setThreadState(threadId, 'comment-editing');

    //
    // Set scope var which will trigger conditional
    // CSS classes via `ng-class` / DOM presence via `ng-if`
    //
    $scope.editingComment = true; // assume scope knows which comment
}


//
//
// Show a tooltip when edit comment icon is hovered
//
// @since 0.4.5-1
//
//
function editTooltip () {
    //
    // assume we know that `this` is the elem bound by `data-ng-hover`
    //
    var $editHoverArea = $(this);

    // hide the "Reply" tooltip elem which we can find as a result
    // of the `data-target` attribute on the elem that triggers replyTooltip()
    $('#replyTooltip').hide();

    $editHoverArea
        .tooltip({
            title: 'Edit Comment',
            placement: 'left auto',
            container: 'body'
        })
        .tooltip('show')
        .on('mouseleave', function (event) {
            $replyHoverArea.tooltip('hide');
            // un-hide the "Reply" tooltip
            $('#replyTooltip').show();
        });
}


//
//
// Reply to comment thread
//
// @since 0.4.5-1
// @param {guid} threadId     Thread involved
//
//
function reply (threadId) {
    // [assume this method knows what angular is]
    var $scope = angular.scope;
    var $thread = $('#thread' + threadId);

    setThreadState(threadId, 'comment-editing');

    //
    // Set scope var which will trigger conditional
    // CSS classes via `ng-class` / DOM presence via `ng-if`
    //
    $scope.editingComment = true; // assume scope knows which comment
    $scope.commentIsReply = true; // ""

    //
    // Inject comment-reply DOM (assume $scope.newCommentReply is defined)
    //
    $thread.append($scope.newCommentReply);
}


//
//
// Show a tooltip when last comment in the thread is hovered
//
// @since 0.4.5-1
//
//
function replyTooltip () {
    //
    // assume we know that `this` is the elem bound by `data-ng-hover`
    //
    var $replyHoverArea = $(this);

    $replyHoverArea
        .tooltip({
            title: 'Reply',
            placement: 'follow'
        })
        .tooltip('show')
        .on('mouseleave', function (event) {
            $replyHoverArea.tooltip('hide');
        });
}

Wells

Use a well as a simple effect on an element to give it a contained, inset effect.

Default well

Look, I'm in a well! 
<div class="well">...</div>

Optional classes

Control padding and rounded corners with two optional modifier classes.

Look, I'm in a well! 
<div class="well well-lg">...</div>
Look, I'm in a well! 
<div class="well well-sm">...</div>
